text:
Stew was amazing. I followed some of the advice that others have mentioned and before searing the meat I tossed it in a Ziplock bag with 1/4 cup of flour, 1/4 tsp of onion powder, garlic powder and pepper. I also added 1/2 cup of red wine during deglazing process, 1/2 tsp of ketchup, A1, and worcestershire sauce after I added the potatoes, carrots and celery and 1/2 cup of barley during the last 30 min. I wasn't sure if 2 hours was enough time to cook as my potatoes and carrots were still undercooked. Next time I will either simmer for more than 2 hours or just throw everything in the crock pot. Other than that it was delicious and recommend.

text:
This is an awesome stew template to follow.  This was the first stew I ever made and I found it simple.  The first time I used this recipe I found it to be way too salty, so I cut down on the bouillon the second time. I also used a flour and milk mixture in addition to some low fat sour cream I had in the fridge instead of cornstarch.  This thickened it up nicely and made a beautiful gravy.  I'm not sure if I cut my vegetables too small, but I found that even half an hour of simmering with the veggies left them mushy, never mind the suggested 1 hr.  I also added worcestershire sauce as well as basil and garlic. I'll definitely be making this again - third time's a charm.

text:
Excellent.  I did my best to follow, but made a few additions along the way.  I quadrupled the amount of cornstarch, added an extra cup of broth, a few shakes of dried chili pepper seeds (a nice "bite"), a small handful of cilantro toward the end (lots of flavor), a cup of wine, and a squirt of ketchup. I fished some of the celery out and tossed them because they seemed to be taking over.  My (critical) boyfriend said it was incredible, didn't hesitate when I asked if I couple put some in a bowl for work the next day (he usually goes out for lunch so what an honor!) and was befuddled that he wasn't a carrot eater but loved them in this stew.

text:
This was some darn good beef stew! I deviated from the recipe. I coated the beef in flour before browning in the pot. I browned the beef and put the flour used for coating into the pot with 1 box and one can of beef broth. (I also find bouillon too salty.) The flour made for an amazing stew gravy. I only simmered the beef for 40 mins. before adding the vegetables. Instead of celery, I used one green bell pepper cut to about 3/4" size. Because I used the flour in the gravy, I skipped the corn starch (cs makes things too gelatinous for my taste.)

This is the best stew I've ever had! We added half a Rutabaga(diced), as well as one large Parsnip(Also diced). Also increased the veggies(not sure how much, but there was at least double the potato) We made this in our crock pot slow cooker, and added more water and an additional bouillon cube as well as a squirt of lemon, and a pinch of salt and garlic. And of course, we added some dumplings.
We've made it twice so far, and this will absolutely be our go-to recipe for when we want a hearty, filling and drool-worthy stew.
I think next time we might add some mushrooms as well, I think the taste would compliment this stew rather well.

text:
I agree with Chuck about browning this meat before making the stew.  The only thing I did differently is to use a pressure cooker and adjust spices similar to Chuck's.  The pressure cooker obviously cuts the cooking time. I never see reviews where anyone has used a pressure cooker, but I would be lost without mine.  The pressure infuses the flavors into the vegetables, in particular and makes the meat almost fall apart, depending on how long you cook it.  Some may not prefer their stew this way, but mine always gets raves.

None
text:
I used one potato, peeled, diced up into small pieces (almost cubed), as an additive to the first hour of summer with about 45 mins left to achieve the starch I needed for thickness; used no corn starch.  I also seasoned the cubed beef overnight in some red wine and Worcestershire sauce (to cover) after rubbing the beef with Montreal Steak Seasoning.  I added dried rosemary and the garlic powder, but I turned the dried rosemary into a powder in my mortar and pestle.  I can only say the house smells incredible, and I'm drooling waiting to taste it!  Perfect fall weather eats!

text:
Very good. I did make a few changes, I dusted the beef in 1/4 c flour, 1tsp garlic powder and pepper, shaken in a plastic bag? Always use canola when browning meat, it gets much hotter than vegetable and will seer the meat while sealing in the juices. Make sue oil is good and hot before adding meat. I added 3/4 of cup of red wine to the the broth.  If you wouldn't drink a glass of the wine then you shouldn't use it in your recipes, only the good stuff. Added 1tsp of basil. I also did as Chuck did and added more vegetables, (used red skin potatoes with skins on) and1 tablespoon each of ketchup, A1 and Worcester Sauce. I also doubled the corn starch as I wanted it thicker. I served it in bread bowls and it was yummy!

Made this today.  My first beef stew and it was wonderful. As always, unless baking and sometimes even then, I use recipes as guidelines.  I did use  wine and beef broth instead of the bullion as I don't care for it. I actually used a crock pot for this recipe.  I coated the beef in flour and browned it in a frying pan with a small amount of olive oil, while the bullion was dissolving in beef broth (instead of water).  I added the ingredients listed here, but also added oregano and garlic powder.  I added just a little more flour than the recipe called for, because the slow cooker never brought it to a boil, there was much more broth.  It was not thick, but not too soupy.  I let it cook on low overnight, and added corn & green beans just before serving.  Delicious!  I shared with several neighbors and my fiance.  EVERYONE loved it!  DHilton1978@gmail.com

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
made several modifications according to the directions of other reviewers: in a bag I put 1/4 cup flour, teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder. 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Put the stew meat in, and shook it up baby! Then I cooked it up in my ( cast iron ) dutch oven and seared in those flavors. This really put some great flavor on that meat and the yummy bits stuck to the bottom of the cast iron pan easily came off during the deglazing with the liquids. I didn't cut back on any liquids..actually you will probably want to add more towards the middle-end of the cooking time. I used 1/2 cup of red wine during the deglazing with the other liquids.

So surprised at how easy making beef stew was & with great results.
Only made half reciepe & followed a few tips about preseasoning, coating the meat in flour & searing it before starting the soup. text:
This stew is great! I've made it twice now, and my picky bf says it's the best he's ever had. It's simple to make, though i'd say the prep time is more like an hour. The only change I made was doubling the corn starch in an attempt to make it thicker. The sauce/gravy still comes out a little thinner than your typical beef stew, but it's very flavorful and I don't think it detracts from the recipe at all. I will definitely be making this time and time again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/871418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent, but I did makes come changes. I doubled the recipe because I always try to make enough for at least two meals, and freeze one for later. I followed Chuck's suggestion to put flour, garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper in a bag and shake the meat in the mixture. I also increased all of the veggies, and used beef broth instead of water and bouillon. I added ketchup, A-1 sauce, and worcestershire sauce as suggested by Chuck. At the end, I used garbanzo bean flour instead of cornstarch to thicken the gravy for the additional nutrients. Even though I made some modifications, this is an excellent recipe as-is. I would recommend anyone to try it.

UPDATE 9/123/14
I thought I might add that last night I decided to try this recipe in a pressure cooker. Naturally, most of the prep time for adding ingredients and cutting and chopping was not reduced, but the cook time was reduced significantly. I did everything as previously stated, but pressure cooked the beef and everything but the potatoes, carrots, onion, and celery for 10 minutes. Then I added the veggies and pressure cooked for another 10 minutes. Then I thickened the gravy with the cornstarch mixture. It turned out great and the beef was incredibly tender.

text:
This recipe is wonderful!  I don't think it needs much alteration, if any.  Important note, though, I find that the meat will not get tender if you are lifting the lid to stir this (or smell it!), so do your best to resist removing the lid other than when you add the veggies.  Kind of like using a slow cooker...  When I take care not to lift the lid, the meat is SOOOOOOOO unbelievably melt-in-your mouth that I wish I had multiplied the recipe by 3!!!

userID:
3523913
Display Name:
needsomezzzs
isPro:

16

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stew was so good my kids even said "this is the best stew I have ever had!". I made a few changes after reading other comments. In a plastic bag I put 1/4 cup flour, teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder. 1/2 teaspoon of pepper and mustard powder. The I added the stew meat in batches and shook it. Then I cooked it in my dutch oven with some oil till lighly browned. This adds excellent flavor to the meat. I then browned the onion in the remaining oil and scrapped up those brown bits on the bottom of the pot. Once the onion was translucent I deglazed the rest with about a 1/2 cup of red wine. I cooked that for about 5 minutes before adding the meat and rest of the liquids to cook of some of the alcohol. I did add more vegetables as others suggested (1 more carrot, celery, potato) I added 1/2 of an extra onion with the addition of the veggies. I also took the advice of another reviewer and added 1 tblsp of ketchup, HP Sauce, and worcestershire sauce -great advice...I was told by my husband "I would pay money for this...restaurant quality!"

text:
Excellent basic beef stew.  I didn't have red wine on hand so I searched for a recipe that does not include it and came up with this one.  The meat was tender (even without the wine) and I really liked the spice combination.   I was hesitant to use so much rosemary with beef but I'm glad I made the stew as written.  The only changes I made were: 1)  saute the onion with the beef (instead of adding it with the other veggies) and 2) double the corn starch because we like a thick stew.   I will definately make this again.

text:
I must say, I feel like I blew it by NOT reading others reviews first! The recipe was FAR too liquidy. More like soup. I had flour in the house, no cornstarch, and used equivalent quantity, but I can see now that even if I'd used cornstarch, it would of still needed triple the quantity. The flavor was really good. I'd never used rosemary this way either, and the flavor is the reason this didn't drop to 3 stars. I added sweet potatoes, zucchini, mushrooms, and frozen peas as well. Next time I will know better! I'm adding cornstarch to my shopping list right now.

text:
Delicious, no fail stew. If you can cut and simmer, you can do this and it's great. I also made modifications posted by others and made some additional ones of my own. I use red wine, add a little ketchup and tomato sauce, and use herbes de provence since I have a bunch I'm trying use up. Instead of cornstarch I use gravy flour and don't have a problem with it lumping. I put the kids' servings over buttered noodles and mine and DH's over lettuce. Instead of bullion cubes I use the bullion that comes in a jar that you can spoon out--pricey but I like it better.

text:
This was my first time making beef stew, and thanks to this recipe, definetly not my last!  The changes I made were to dredge my beef in plain flour, used powdered boullion, added mushrooms, used Italian seasoning because we were out of parsley, and omitted celery.  Oh yes, and I omitted the cornstarch as it was thick enough without it.  Served with buttermilk biscuits and it was a hit with the whole family!

text:
I intended to make this recipe exactly as it was written, but when I got the adding the rosemary part, I realized I was out, so I put tarragon in it instead and thought it turned out just great.  First beef stew attempt.  It was a little bit more liquid-y on the first day, but the second and third days of leftovers were a perfect consistency and was glad I didn't initially thicken it up based on the other reviews.   I added a few sprinkles of tabasco (first day) and cholula (the second day) right as I eating it and it gave it a great kick. I will try it with the intended rosemary the next time and compare.

text:
This beef stew was great!! I think it'll do nicely as a base recipe. I followed the reviews and used the garlic/onion powder/black pepper flour mixture for the beef and I added the three sauces an hour into cooking. At that point I added potatoes and onions. Thirty minutes later I added corn, tomatoes, mushrooms and more onions. It was fabulous. I didn't need to add any cornstarch at the end because it had thickened up nicely on its own. The man of my house liked it and also had it for leftovers the next day and he only does that if he likes it. Thank you!!! =)

userID:
3952037
Display Name:
Jo
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is how I have been doing my beef stew for years. However, I cube my meat and toss in a plastic ziplock bag with flour. Make sure the meat is well coated. Drop in pan and brown on high heat. Use wine if you like to deglaze pan, and then the remaining ingredients. Bring to a good simmer put on the lid and toss in oven for an hour. I crush my rosemary with a pestle and that really releases the flavor. This is a great recipe. Very basic, easy and lots of flavor.

I made several of the recommended changes: 1 c. of red wine in place of 1 c. of the water, coating the beef with flour/pepper/garlic powder before browning, adding a Tbs of ketchup and worchestshire sauce. I also used chicken broth in place of beef bouillon, and fresh rosemary because that's what I had. I found that I needed to add more liquid after the first hour-- about a cup. Then I omitted the cornstarch at the end because it was thick enough (stew but not thick gravy). Hearty and delicious!

text:
This method of making beef stew was the most successful for me.  I will never make beef stew in the crockpot again!  The meat was so moist and tender, and tasty.  I didn't have the seasonings at hand.  Used chicken bouillon (which was a tad bit too sweet - would have been better with beef), worchestshire, a bit of soy, thyme, rosemary.  I also omitted the celery.  I didn't use cornstarch but had some smaller pieces  of potato that overcooked and fell apart to thicken the stew.   Will definitely be making this again and again.  Browning the meat is a must!  Aside from that, experiment with the seasonings.

text:
Excellent flavors! My boyfriend and I have made this stew twice now (both times using elk meat) and it has turned out great! We followed the advice of earlier reviews and tossed the meat with garlic, rosemary, and flour prior to browning it and then placing it in the broth mixture. The meat turned out so tender it almost melts in your mouth!   We also added a tablespoon of both A1 sauce and Worcheshire sauce for a little extra boost of flavor. It was yummy! I used red potatoes and added them with only 45 minutes remaining so they wouldn't get too soggy.  We had rave reviews from our guests! Will definitely make many, many more times!

country:
None
text:
YUMMM eating for days. This is the first time I had ever made beef stew and it was pretty easy. Make sure not to add any additional salt before you taste it. The bouillon adds plenty. I coated the beef in 1/4 cup of flour and a teaspoon each of garlic and onion powder and 1/2 teaspoon or pepper. I used 3 1/2 cups water and 1/2 cup of red wine for starters. I ended up adding about another 3/4 cup of water and splash of wine in the second hour of cooking. I also took the advice of others and used 6 teaspoons of cornstarch and water to thicken. I thought there were plenty of vegetables and no need to add more as others had recommended.

text:
Mmmmmmm!  Instead of the beef bouillion and water, I used two 32 oz. beef stock boxes and approximately three cups of a nice red cabernet wine.  I added extra carrots and potatoes and threw in a box of freshly sliced baby bella mushrooms but eliminated the celery since I'm not a big fan of it. Added two bay leaves during the cooking process for additional flavor.  I also added garlic powder, onion powder and black pepper to a flour mix that I coated the meat with prior to cooking it.  Putting the mix in a plastic bag and adding the meat will evenly coat the meat.  Will definitely be making again.

text:
Thank you, Paula, for the wonderful recipe. After learning some from the reviews and other recipes, I added some changes.  My difficult husband and I loved it so much.    I made it for 6 servings, and here is the changes: 1. Yes! I followed the ziploc bag advice (1/4 cup flour, 1tsp garlic and oniln powder) and the beef and shake it. 2. Used 4 carrots and stalks celery 3. Used beer for the half amount of the water 4. 2 cloves of garlic, minced 5. 1 tbs of paprika 6. 1 bay leaf 7. 1 1/2 tsp Worcestershire sauce  With the above changes, I just followed as directed.  It is the most wonderful beef stew I have ever had!

text:
Ok, I know many of you hate when people alter the recipe, but here's what I did. I scaled the recipe in half, first of all. I added 3 cloves of chopped garlic while sauteing the beef, as well as some Montreal Chicken Seasoning. I used fresh rosemary and parsely (three times the amount of dried herbs). I used beef broth instead of the boullion, 1 and a half cans, to be exact. I put in the celery, carrots, and onion first, then added the potatoes during the last half hour of cooking. I also added cut green beans. I doubled the amount of starch as well. The end result was phenomenal. My boyfriend said it was the best beef stew he'd ever had!

text:
This was really good, but with some changes,  I also floured the meat, sub. 1/2 C. wine for the water, and deglazed the pan with the wine after I took the meat out. Added the meat back and better then boullion disolved in water.  I also doubled the cornstarch and water and simmered 1/2 hr. but it wasn't thick enough so I added another 2 TBS. of both and about 2 TBS of tomato paste.  Simmered another 1/2 hr. or longer but I would have liked it a little thicker.

Delicious!  I doubled the water too and added 2 packets of au jus which gave it a rich brown color.  I had left over sirlion from the 4th that we grilled and I couldn't bare to see it wasted so I cut it up and froze it until I could try this recipe.  I also used the suggestion to brown my meat in a couple T of flour too.  I also had 4 cobs of corn that had already been cooked, so I cut the corn off the cob and threw that in too.  What a great way to use up what was in my fridge!  It was just the right thickness and flavor.  A true comfort food recipte that I will make again and again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was better than expected. I modified the recipe slightly and changed or added: 1.75lbs (i cubed to 3/4") stew meat, about a 1.5c baby carrots halved or third instead of large carrots, 4 med/large yukon gold potatoes peeled and chopped to 3/4" cubes, 4oz sliced mushrooms, decreased pepper to 1/4t-but added 1/2t montreal steak seasoning for added kick, and 1/3C flour to dredge meat prior to browning + remaining flour for thickening instead of cornstarch. I was running short on time so i simmered meat and potatoes together for 1/2 hr, then added remaining ingredients as recipe stated for additional 1 hr 10 min except for the mushrooms which i added last 1/2 hr. Two preschoolers and picky husband all liked it! Meat was tender, not tough and veggies cooked just right. Served with a leftover wholegrain sourdough bread.

This stew was 5-star in a comfort-food sort of way.  It was just like a recipe my mom used when I was a kid.  I took the advice of some reviews and coated my meat in flour to brown, but I don't think this was necessary.  I didn't add the corn starch at the end because it had already become very thick -- I had to add water twice to keep it from burning, and I had it covered!  Next time I'll stick with the recipe as written.

text:
This beef stew has become a regular favorite in my household.  I make it with 1 tsp. of Italian Seasoning since I don't have dried rosemary and it always comes out fantastic.  I usually add a bit more water (1/2 - 1 cup more) since it is pretty spicy.  I've made other "thicker" beef stews with tomatoes and red wine but this is totally different.  It's more like beef soup with vegetables and my husband and I LOVE it everytime.

text:
Wow, this was delicious! It had so much flavor and the meat was very tender. After cooking the meat for an hour I let it sit (with the stove off) for almost another hour. I also added 1 package of dry brown onion soup mix when I added the carrots and potatoes. Then I cooked it for only about 30 minutes...the carrots and potatoes were done. I put it in a hotpot (something they use here in Africa) and kept it warm for three hours until we were ready to eat. The whole family loved it! I just made it yesterday, and they're ready for me to make it again!

text:
I took pieces of all the advice and came up with some additions.  Instead of 4 cups of water, I used 3 cups and 1 cup of red wine.  I also used two cloves of chopped garlic when I browned the beef.  I added an extra potato which pretty much thickened the stew so the extra corn starch wasn't needed.  A small can of tomato paste was added during the last simmer.  Came out really great, I was impressed since I think I have pretty much cooked 5 dishes in my whole life.  Great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great when you want beef stew in a hurry. I used a pressure cooker both times i've made this dish. First i browned the seasoned(salt & pepper) beef, then added all my ingredients minus the slurry. I use yukon gold potatoes instead of russet, they keep their shape better. Since i needed to cut back on the liquid (b/c i used a pressure cooker)I used two cans of beef broth instead of the water & bullion mix. After 25 minutes in the pressure cooker,i reseasoned, and then added the slurry, brought stew to a boil, and it was ready to eat. Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe (=

This stew was great!  I did make a few substitutions - I didn't have any beef boullion so I used 2 cans beef broth.  I also forgot to add onion, and substituted flour for the cornstarch.  Also, I ended up needing to leave about half way through cooking, so it cooked (on low) for ~1 hour longer than the recipe called for, and it still turned out wonderful.  I halved the recipe, but there are only 2 of us, so we had a little over half leftover, and my husband ate ALL the leftovers for lunch the next day!  I will definitely be making this again.

This is THE Beef Stew recipe.  It's never been one of my favorite meals until now.  Instead of the cornstarch, I dredged the meat in flour and browned it a batch at a time in the dutch oven. The result is a thick, rich, flavorful stew that everyone I make it for proclaims is the best ever!  Thank you for this recipe!

Great Recipe!  I used salt, pepper and garlic powder to season the meat while it cooked.  I used premade beef broth instead of water and added a few bay leaves with the rosemary while the beef simmered.  Instead of corn starch I used Potato Buds (1-2 cups, depending on preference) to thicken the stew - better consistency and taste!  Easy to make - a keeper!

text:
This is my favorite beef stew recipe of all time and is so yummy it reminds me of my grandmother’s cooking!  I shake the beef cubes in a bag first with flour, salt and pepper before browning. Then in a Dutch oven I brown the onion with a ton of minced garlic and add a cup+ of red wine that I bring to a boil before adding a bay leaf.  In the last 20 minutes or so my husband adds his homemade dumplings and it’s perfection!  The kids gobble it up.

I made this over the weekend and WOW, was it GOOD! I will be making this quite often from now on!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stew is very good! I did make some changes based on the reviews: Here is what I did. in a bag I put 1/4 cup flour, teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder. 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Put the stew meat in, and shook it up baby! Then I cooked it up in my ( cast iron ) dutch oven and seared in those flavors. This really put some great flavor on that meat and the yummy bits stuck to the bottom of the cast iron pan easily came off during the deglazing with the liquids. I didn't cut back on any liquids..actually you will probably want to add more towards the middle-end of the cooking time. I used 1/2 cup of red wine during the deglazing with the other liquids. I thought it needed more vegetables since I made this recipe 2 weeks ago staying true to the recipe..but this time when I did it, I added an extra ( 1 more carrot, celery, potato ) I added 1/2 of an extra onion. I also took the advise of another reviewer and added 1 tblspn each of ketchup, A-1 sauce, and wistersire sauce that really gave it some full-bodied flavor...

userID:

Display Name:
Julia Higgins

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5725589.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe as a base and have made it several times with slight variations. I always use white sweet potatoes instead of regular potatoes which creates a wonderful savory sweetness. As per other reviews, I coat the beef with a flour mixture (1/4 c flour, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp pepper) and throw that all into a gallon ziplock back with the beef and shake it up) before browning. There never seems to be enough liquid so after the first hour I add a beer (a pale ale is what I had) and this time a can of spicy tomato juice (V8). I always use a a few extra carrots and celery. I didn't have beef bouillon this time so used chicken broth instead and I couldn't even tell the difference. It makes a lot and we've eaten it  for dinner 3 nights in a row and I think maybe it's more delicious each day. I always wonder why I don't make this more. It is so easy, makes great leftovers and I feel like it's hard to mess it up. It has always turned out great.

So I actually tweaked a few things on this recipe and it came out amazing. I followed the suggestion of other reviews and tossed the beef in 1/4 cup flour and 1tsp of both onion and garlic powders and 1/2 tsp of pepper before browning. When I first added the water I added 1 tsp of basil and 1/4 tsp of Thyme, 1 tbsp of both Worcestershire Sauce and Balsamic Vinegar. Then I added 1 additional cup of water and 1 additional bouillon when I added the veggies. It was perfection!

userID:
3607676
Display Name:
Jasmine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick and easy to prepare and was ready to eat in 2 hours. I did make a few adjustments by following another person’s review. I put 1/4 cup flour, a tbsp each of pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder in zip lock bag then added beef to coat. Then I sautéed garlic before adding beef to olive oil to brown and sear in flavor. I didn’t use red wine to deglaze prior to adding beef stock but next time I will. Then I added stock and veggies. In addition to what the original recipe called for I did add Worcestershire sauce and ketchup for additional flavor like one review had said along with salt and pepper for flavoring. Overall this was a good meal for a cold New England evening. My husband and 3 year old enjoyed it too!
Review:
Rating:
4

I enjoyed the stew, and it made a decent size batch.  Like others have mentioned, it did need a bit more water, and i had to add extra cornstarch to thicken. Next time, I will try rosemary, and see which one I like best.

text:
I am unsaving all my other beef stew recipes. This is that good. I subbed frozen mixed veggies (diced carrots, corn, and green beans) for the carrots in an effort to empty the freezer, and I halved the recipe since we just didn't need that much stew. I wish I had made the full recipe and frozen half instead now, though! Lesson learned. The flavor is rich, and the stew is very hearty... pure comfort food. Serve with crusty bread and enjoy!

country:
None
text:
It was more bland than I thought it would be with the following changes I picked up from other cooks:
---before cooking, coat the meat in 1/4 cup flour, 1 Tblsp each garlic & onion powder, 1/2 tsp. each seasoned salt & pepper                                                                                                        ---1 cup red wine to deglaze pot after meat cooked
---1 Tblsp each worcestshire sauce and ketchup, 2 tsp. fish sauce (I didn't have A1 sauce) with the liquids
---I added one extra carrot and celery & 1/2 extra onion
---Smashed 6-8 pieces of potato to thicken
---cooked an extra 15 minutes with cover off to thicken
---added steamed peas to the individual bowls before serving

text:
I made a few small changes and it turned out great. Instead of billion cubes I used Better than Bullion paste. A ton better on beef flavor and hardly any salt so you can salt as needed. I added a couple cloves of minced garlic. On the cornstarch I used 3 tsps with 3 tsps cold water. I recommend red skin potatoes as the russets break down and become mushy before the other vegetables cook. Also cut the carrots into thinner pieces of you want them to absorb the beef flavor. Other than that great recipe.

userID:
3943807
Display Name:
Sheltielove
isPro:
False

36

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/771255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious, flavorful stew with fork tender beef.  Loved the simplicity of this recipe.  Sure, you could add wine, beer, catsup or any number of things you find in your pantry, but  there is absolutely no need as long as you use  a good sear to carmelize the meat.  Here's how to get perfectly carmelized, tender beef in your stew:  Forget the overpriced cubed stew meat (who knows what it is or where it's been) and go for a 3 pound chuck roast instead.  Chuck is your best choice.  Slice into cubes yourself.  Leave on a little of the fat for flavor, but don't go crazy.  You can skim the fat later as you cool the stew.  Flour or don't  flour  your beef prior to your sear - my personal preference is to flour to avoid some of the spatter when you sear in the oil, and to  provide thickening .  The critical step: Each cube should be seared on every side until all sides are a  rich brown - darker than what is shown in the video.  Use medium high heat.  It's improtant to sear your beef in batches.  If you crowd the pan, you get a grey mess of steamed beef.  Don't stir while you sear.  Let each side get carmelized and medium brown, then turn with tongs as in the video.  When you smell the wonderful aroma of browned beef, it's ready to turn.  I use my Dutch oven.  It takes me 20 minutes or so to batch cook and sear my beef.  Follow Paula's  instructions on when to add the vegetables and how long to cook the stew to the "t" - she knows her stuff when it comes to braising a stew!  I have fo
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-03-22T18:52:19.3

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was my 1st go at beef stew. It turned out delicious!
I followed a few reviewer suggestions and added a bit of ketchup and steak sauce, but don’t think it added any real flavor to the end result.

I used beef stock and red wine instead of boulion. I had to add quite a bit of salt and pepper going this route. I also tripled the cornstarch slurry. (Tablespoons instead of teaspoons)

The only thing I would do different next time is browning meat in a skillet in batches then deglazing with wine or broth and adding to the pot.
I used a black angus chuck roast that I cubed. It would have been better if I had rendered more fat while browning.

This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
Delicious!
This stew was fantastic, very hearty and perfect for those cold winter nights when all you want is something to warm you up! I did make a few modifications, I followed a previous reviewer's recommendations. I threw the cubed beef into a giant zip lock with some flour, onion powder, garlic powder and pepper. I cooked it up and left the brown bits in my pot. They dissolve throughout the cooking. I also used 6 beef bouillons instead of 4 and I also used more of the veggies and used red potatoes instead. I just threw them in whole and they turned out perfectly! No mushiness at all. I did end up having to add another half cup of water. After 2 hours it was ready and boy was it divine! Will definitely be making it again!

text:
This got a big thumbs up from my husband, and I liked it, too.

I followed the recipe as written, with one change.  By the time I added the veggies, almost all the liquid had cooked off.  To avoid burning, and to make sure the veggies cooked, I added enough chicken broth to just cover the vegetables.  Enough of that cooked off to leave us with a thick, delicious stew with little bit of broth.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6134142.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did make a few changes based on other reviews. I put the stew meat in a bag and tossed it in flour, black pepper, garlic powder, and season salt (that was my own throw in); before browning it. I also didn't use and parsley, but that was purely because I strongly dislike it. I only used two (2) bullion cubes because of the size of the ones I have. Then I subbed 1 cup of the water with 1/4 red wine, 3/4 cup extra beef broth. Then at the end I found that it was ultimately in need of a little more flavoring, so I added some more garlic powder, season salt, and 21 seasoning salut from Trader Joe's (all measured to taste). Like everyone else mentioned, it's overall a good recipe but most people have preferred to make a few alterations based on their tastebuds.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made variations of this recipe for years and improvise around the basic ingredients. Just made it with organic AAA beef cubes, trimmed and cut in half, and 6 trimmed lamb chops -- all were reduced for quick sale; fresh rosemary, bay leaf, ground coriander seeds, and parsley all from the front garden, and aromatic organic oregano from Mt. Athos in Greece; organic veggies -- baby potatoes, one small onion, carrots , leeks, and celery; added a few rough chopped cloves of fresh garlic and a few squirts of Petti 'doppio' tomato paste (from the tube). A few 'glugs' of Chilean red wine for good measure too.

You can't go wrong. Someone in the house will probably want me to add curry powder, but I'll  talk them into doing that with the leftover batch :-) A nice bottle of C.C. Jentsch "The Chase" red wine (Okanagan, BC) and dinner is slow cooking and ready in a few hours :-)

text:
I added flour, onion and garlic to the meat before browning,  used 1/3 of a cup of apple cider vinegar to deglaze the pan, and also added Worcestershire sauce and some BBQ sauce to the liquids at the final stage.  Without those additions it would have been too bland, but was great with those changes.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
0
userID:
15710320
Display Name:
LanaKitKat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
127
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay,  real talk: this recipe is amazing.  I've lurked on AllRecipes for years but never reviewed until now,  it's that good.   The meat is incredibly tender and the veggies still have a little snap to them,  rather than being mushy and without any distinct flavor (like they can get to be in other stews). This will be a go-to for the rest of my life. 

I hate to be that person, but I DID make a few additions. However,  I don't think they're necessary (just bonuses!). First, I cut up and browned 6 slices of bacon and set aside in a bowl for later--I didn't have any oil so I had to improvise!  While I did that,  I let the beef come to room temp then tossed it in a bag with 1/4 cup flour, about a teaspoon of garlic powder, and a little white pepper.  I then browned the meat in the bacon grease before adding liquids.  I simmered uncovered for the first hour because I missed that in the directions (oops!).  And I did use beef broth because it was all I had!  After I added the veggies,  I put a little bit of Worcestershire sauce in, too (because why not?). 

The result: fall-apart meat that I only thought was possible in the slow-cooker, perfectly cooked veggies,  and a thick,  flavorful gravy.  You could follow the directions to a T or add/ remove/ substitute ingredients and I guarantee you'll come out with an awesome stew!

userID:
17822703
Display Name:
GD67
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This will be my primary Beef Stew recipe.  It's really good!  I've taken tips from others and made the following revisions:  I tossed the cubed stew meat in a gallon size freezer bag with 1/4 cup wheat flour, a teaspoon each of garlic powder, onion powder and a 1/2 teaspoon of pepper.  I used a large cast iron Dutch oven for browning the meat and then added everything else to the same pot once the meat was ready.  I added additional carrots, onions, celery, fresh parsley and used small red potatoes cut in half (not peeled).  I added 1 tbsp Stubb's Original BBQ Sauce, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1/2 cup red wine and I used Better than Bouillon paste instead of cubes.  I also doubled the amount of cornstarch.  Easy to make and with using just the Dutch oven, cleanup is quick.  Of course, it gets even more flavorful the next day.  So good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  I used 2 cans of beef broth and reduced the salt.  We prefer more veggies and less meat.  The recipe was halved.  Used only 1/2 lb of meat and cut it into small spoon size pieces.  As the others suggested, salt, pepper and 1 tblsp of flour was sprinkled on the meat before browning in the pot with 2 tsp veg oil.  1 and 1/2 cans Beef broth was added.  The remaining broth was added to 2 tblsp each of flour and cornstarch, 1/4 tsp of salt, pepper, parsley and a dash/pinch of garlic powder and rosemary.  Sweet onion was used and 1 cup of peas was added 10 mins before adding the seasoned broth.  It thickened right away.  My Son said it was pretty as a picture.  It tasted great.  I might try adding mushrooms next time.

text:
This is my new "go to" stew recipe. I did make the following adjustments:
I added 2 Tbsp of flour, 1 Tbsp of paprika, and 1 Tbsp dry mustard into a large ziplock bag and coated the meat pieces completely prior to browing in my cast iron pot.
I added about 1/3 cup of worchestershire, and used the organic beef stock (purchased from Costco).
The one mistake I did make was that I added seasoning salt and a bit of brown gravy mix (to thicken the broth), and it made it more salty than I would have wanted. Otherwise, it was great.
Served with cheese biscuits, and voila - supper was served!

It sounds like a lot but I think it really helped to give the entire dish some more flavor. especially since beef stock can be a bit bland in my opinion.

userID:
21332528
Display Name:
Taylor B
isPro:
False
followersCount:

1
favoritesCount:
41
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5569379.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time ever making beef stew. I am very happy with the way it turned out. I did a few things differently though. Instead of just putting the beef in the crockpot ( if you use a slow cooker for about 6 hours it's so much better. The meat is softer too) 

I did 2 pounds beef stew meat put one pound at a time in a freezer bag with 1 cup flower, 2 teaspoons garlic powder, 1 teaspoon onion powder, 1 teaspoon dried parsley, 1 teaspoon and 1 teaspoon dried oregano. I shook it all together and pressed the flour into the meat. I then put enough oil in a pan to cook the flour into the meat. Doing it this way made the stew a little thicker. The last 20 minutes, I added 2 teaspoons of corn starch and 2 teaspoons water and mixed together in a bowl. I waited 10 minutes the stew still seemed a little too watery. I took a measuring cup and scooped out a bit of the "broth" from the crock pot and mixed together 1 more teaspoon of corn starch and 1 teaspoon of water. I mixed it together again and poured it into the measuring cup that had the beef stew broth to see if it made it too thick. It didn't! So I poured the measuring cup with the corn starch already mixed into it, into my crockpot and it was perfect. If you're looking for beef stew that's a little thicker than what you get following this receipe - try what I did. I was very happy with the way it all turned out.
Review:

5

text:
I made this tonight and it was wonderful.  I did make a few changes based on what other people said.  I used 1/4 cup flour mixed with 1 tsp. garlic powder, 1 tsp. onion powder and 1/2 tsp black pepper and shook the beef in a ziplock bag, then browned the beef.  I then removed the beef from my dutch oven and deglazed the pot with 1/2 cup of red wine, then added the stock & beef cubes and followed the rest of the recipe as stated.  Oh, and I did use about double the cornstarch/water mixture because I like a thicker stew.

text:
First time making a traditional stew, turned out really tender. I added a cup of red Shiraz wine to the stock, and cut out one of the beef bullion cubes, and added more rosemary and pepper, and some leek. I also dredged the beef cubes in flour before browning, although I didn't find it did too much for me (still added 3 tsp corn starch). 

Cooked over 2-3 hours and was very tender and soft and didn't have that "thick beef " taste.  Wish I had more carrots on had, would have added a wonderful sweetness! Pretty impressed with such a simple recipe!

I have made this recipe 3 -4 Times now an we like it more every time.  My only change has been to save the last spoonful of peas from diners during the month and store them in the freezer.   10 minutes before the end of the stew cooking time I toss them in.  Adds flavor and color both!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this recipe was great. I did make it in the slow cooker for the eight hours. I just threw in all the Raw food. I did not brown the meat beforehand. I first added the meat, then I just piled everything else on top of the meat. I did put the two teaspoons of water in a measuring cup along with two teaspoons of flour. I did mix it together and added it to the slow cooker. And then to top it all off, I added a box of penne pasta. I mixed everything all together.  After about 6 hours, I had to add 2 cans of beef broth to cover the beef and vegetables again.  It came out just awesome.  I would make this again but would try it on the stove top.

country:
None
text:
This recipe earned rave reviews from my husband and friends.  There were a few changes- I put the carrots in about 30 minutes early so they would soften up, and the rest of the veggies about 15 minutes early.  I substituted celery for the onions and added a can of corn.   I also used chicken broth instead of bouillon cubes and water, and tweaked the spices.  I went with 2 teaspoons of oregano, one of rosemary, one of sage, and a few shakes of garlic powder.  We served it over buttered bow tie pasta in bowls, and it was a big hit.

This was easy, and quite tasty!  The only two changes I made:  I used a spring of fresh rosemary (mainly since I didn't have dried, but it tasted wonderful), and after I added the vegetables in, I added a can (2 cups) of beef broth.  The four cups of broth had gotten way too low from the first hour of simmering.  We'll definitely make it again.

userID:
22877933
Display Name:
Greg Laxton
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4606379.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always put the beef cubes in a ziplock bag with a bunch of flour/some salt and black pepper and shake, covering the cubes in a reasonble layer of flour, just so you can't see the red of the meat on any side. Then, I sautee the onions with garlic in butter/oil in the bottom of a pot big enough for all the ingredients plus the broth/wine on medium-high heat. Sautee until the onions are translucent, and pour them into a bowl so you can brown the meat. Add more oil (I use grapeseed oil, as it has a low smoke point and it's actually good for you) and brown as much of the meat as will comfortably fit in the bottom of the pot at a time (you may need to have another bowl to put the first batch of browned meat into temporarily while you brown the second batch). Be sure to just sear the meat on all sides so all sides have been browned a bit, but don't cook any more than that, or the meat will be tough! Remember to add more oil for browning the second batch of meat, as the flour will absorb quite a bit. If you use grapeseed oil, you can be quite liberal with the oil. 

Once the second batch of meat is browned, add back in the first batch to the pot and then add the beef broth (I like to also use some chicken broth with the beef broth for added flavour) and red wine/bay leaves/dried parsley, thyme and toss in the hard vegetables (carrots, potatoes, turnip) and bring to a boil, stirring occasionally. I use worchestershire sauce quite liberally: none of this one or two teaspoons nonsense
Review:

text:
I just wanted to first start by saying this soup tasted just like my grandma’s, so so delicious!!! I pretty much followed the recipe as it was with a few minor adjustments- I? combined a couple of ideas that I got from the reviewer‘s. First I took the suggestion of one reviewer and I braised the meat and a quarter cup of flour, a dash of garlic powder, a dash of ground pepper and a dash of beef seasoning. That really helped to tenderize the meet and it gave great flavor! I simmered to meat with as suggested but only for about 45 minutes. I added in two handfuls of baby carrots and one deseeded tomato. I cooked/simmered that for about 30-35 minutes I added in the potatoes at the last 30 minutes so they wouldn’t get mushy as mentioned by another reviewer. The base was pretty thick so I added in another 3 cups of water and that helped to thin it out a bit. The outcome was perfection! It was so flavorful, the meat practically melted in your mouth and it really hit the spot. I also served the stew with bread and butter. I will definitely be making this again very soon!! Practically melted in your mouth

text:
My husband said this was the best beef stew ever! I made a few changes - instead of bouillon I used consomme and I also used red wine. Skipped the celery. Used flour to thick instead of cornstarch. I also let the meat cook by itself and let it rest overnight before adding the vegetables. It made the meat very flavorful and tender. I grew up hating beef stew, and I absolutely loved this! Also used baby red potatoes so that they would not get mushy (as russets do). Can't recommend this enough!

userID:
5923389
Display Name:
DannyFranky
isPro:
False
followersCount:

10
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My review combines a few techniques from other reviewers and I have to say that this was the best stew I've ever tasted.
I put 1/4 cup of flour, 1 tsp garlic powder, onion powder, 1/2 tsp pepper in a bag and shook the beef up before pan frying in oil until I'd seared and browned the beef. I tossed an onion and a couple cloves of minced garlic in toward the end of browning the beef. I added 1/2 a cup of merlot, a container (4 cups) of beef broth, a tablespoon of "better than bullion" beef flavoring, and a tablespoon of each: ketchup, A-1 steak sauce, and worcestershire sauce. (The depth of flavors from these were unexpectedly amazing.) I chopped up fresh rosemary and parsley, added a couple of dried bay leaves and let it simmer. After about 45 minutes, I threw in the carrots, celery, and chopped baby red potatoes. Let it simmer for another hour. Just before it was ready to serve, I cut up and  pan fried a package of baby portobella mushrooms in a tablespoon and a half of butter and poured the whole pan into the stew. The buttery flavor and texture of the mushrooms was incredible. 

I also made the Allrecipe's Chef John's Buttermilk Biscuits with this recipe and dinner.

I followed the advice of those who went before me, and this was the best, most savory stew I've ever tasted.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-11-07T00:22:41.61
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This was FANTASTIC!  I will be throwing away all of my other stew recipes and replacing it with just this!  During the 2nd simmer, after adding the potatoes and carrots, the liquid reduced to pretty much nothing.  I did have to add another cup of water,  but it instantly made a delicious gravy-like liquid, so no extra bouillon or flavoring was needed.  For spices, I only had fresh rosemary and dried thyme.  It was SO good!  A little parsley at the end would have added a nice touch to brighten up the rather  brown color to this stew, but for flavor, nothing else was needed.

country:

text:
This turned out great!  It was fast and easy and I will definitely be making it again.  I don't use my dutch over much and may have had the heat a little too high as the veggies cooked surprisingly fast and the liquid evaporated a lot.   

To remedy, I doubled the cooking liquid (additional 4 cups water  & 4 bullion cubes), threw in a little more spices to compensate for the extra liquid and pulled the pot off the heat a little early.  Of course more corn starch was needed with the extra liquid, too.  It turned out awesome!  Lots of rich gravy , tender meat and a good ratio of veggies.  

Only other mods: I put a little salt, pepper, and flour on the meat before browning.  I also added some powdered garlic to the pot and added frozen peas after I removed the pot from the heat .  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Made just a few substitutions, but otherwise loved it! The first time, going exactly by the recipe, it was quite dry (in my opinion) and had a bit of a gravy-like texture and if thats the point, then whoopsies cause it wasn’t what I was expecting ahaha. The second, I realized wanted more of a soup/stew rather than regular stew texture, so made sure to really dissolve the bouillon (break 2 cubes instead of 4 into tiny pieces with a fork and then let set in 2 cups of water for around 3-4 hours, stirring occasionally). I also used a full box of Progresso’s beef flavored broth (32 oz [?]) along with the 2 cups of water and bouillon. Ended up with the second time, the boyfriend and I ate half while the roommates ate the other half a few hours later and their beef cubes were even more tender than ours (obviously cause it sat in the broth n such) but I’ll have to figure out how to get the beef cubes to sit in the broth stew mix without running down the flavor for next time...

userID:
20394692
Display Name:
NoxLumos
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
39
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is stew is great with just a few adjustments.  First off,  no self respecting stew would leave out mushrooms.  I carmelize  the onions, together with mushrooms, by heating them on medium high with about a 1/4 cup of sugar and some salt to bring out the liquid to carmelize (about 45 minutes stirring frequently).  Simple flavors, but deeply set by carmelizing and simmering is the best!

The last piece of the puzzle is...add about a cup or so of red wine.  Deepens the flavor!

When done I removed the mushroom and onions and set them aside .  Then I browned the beef with about 3-4 cloves of garlic.  After browning I simmered the beef per the directions, but added thencarmelized onions nd mushrooms 30 minutes into the simmering process.  The carmelized onion/mushroom mix is what brings out the flavor and makes the dish.  

I followed the directions for adding the potatoes, celery, and carrots, but I don’t use cornstarch for thickening.  The only way to go is to make a roux:  1/2 cup flour and 1/2 cup of olive oil (or any oil/fat).  Cook until a blonde or caramel color in the mixture.  Add to the pot for thickening.  It came out great.  Good luck!
Review:

5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Will definitely be making this again! Delicious! I read the reviews and someone suggested tossing the meat in a mixture of 1/4 cup of flour, 1 tsp of onion powder, 1 tsp of garlic powder, and some ground black pepper and then browning it. This added amazing flavour! Next time, I plan to also put some salt into that mixture. I used oregano instead of rosemary just because that was what I had, and used 2 1/2 big cubes of Knorr Beef Stock for 4 cups of water. Another thing I found, is I had to let the stew boil/simmer gently once I added the veggies in before lowering the heat, because after I let it cook for an hour on low the veggies were still raw.

I highly recommend this dish! If you want to get extra yummies, make the No Knead Dutch Oven Bread to dip into the stew as you eat! Super delicious!!

None
text:
I make beef stew often. My only difference with this recipe, as another review is coat beef cubes with flour. Very easy, just shake them in a plastic bag with about a 1/2 cup of flour. I brown on high in the dutch oven. I often add mushrooms, also brown very well. Then proceed as the recipe states. The cornstarch is hardly ever needed. The flour coating should do the thickening for you. Comfort food indeed !

text:
Taste was AMAZING before I put the cornstarch in...just not to my liking.  Will definitely make this again without the cornstarch!  I like the soup version more than the stew version.  The cornstarch removed a lot of the flavor that was amazing!!  Also, I need to remember to cut the potatoes a bit larger and the celery smaller.   I thought the one inch cut meant the celery was only in their for flavor and not meant to be eaten, but the flavor of the celery was AMAZING but I wished that it was in smaller pieces so it would have been easier to eat.  Also the potatoes had a wonderful flavor as well, but needed to have more of them for my taste.

text:
It turned out so incredibly well. The only issues I had with it were all mistakes I made not necessarily the recipe itself. Take the time to seer the meat correctly otherwise you will end up with dry pieces. You would think because it's in liquid it will be moist. Incorrect. A few pieces were too big after I seered them so I cut them in half and forgot to seer the cut side. Believe it or not I could tell which pieces I cut in half. I used a lot more cornstarch than what it calls for but I prefer thick sauce so when I pour it over my biscuits it doesn't soak in as quickly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really enjoyed this recipe, but I did make a few changes. I used about 1/2 a cup of red wine to deglaze the pan. I added a bay leaf to the seasoning, and used much more corn starch to thicken my stew. I also waited until the last 20 minutes to add my potatoes. Simmering them for an hour is way too long ... they would break down into the broth and just create a starchy gravy, with little to no chunks of potato. Mine came out just right at 20 minutes.

DO NOT ADD ANY SALT. You may feel it will need salt as the recipe doesn't call for it but DONT DO IT! if you do, you need to dilute it with a little sugar and cider vinegar. Learned this the hard way but luckily was able to recover it to perfection by adding little sugar and cider vinegar. You will want more stew so add one more cup of water half way through and half cup of WHITE WINE if you have it. Rosemary makes this great, I added another 1tsp of rosemary half way through.. Definitely add MINIMUM 8-10tsp corn starch to 13-15tsp of cold water. Add even more if you want it noticeably thick but the 10tsp won't make it too thick. Following recipe otherwise makes this perfect. The lost star is because 1tsp of cornstarch will make this more of a soup than a stew which could of ruined it!

text:
Followed the recipe precisely - the end result was more of a beef and vegetable broth soup. I had to add an additional 1/2 cup of cornstarch-&-water agent to thicken the gravy, double the herbs and serve it with garlic bread to make it a substantial meal. I agree with the other reviewers - modifications need to be made to make this a 5-star recipe. But then again, next time  I will probably just invest the time into making a proper beef bourguignon à la Julia Child.

text:
Didn't have beef bouillon so we used chicken bouillon instead. I used 3 Table Spoons of Chicken Bouillon when I cooked the meat down then added enough water for the meat and veggies to float. If you don't need more water don't add any. I then poured in a spiral of Organic Soy Sauce. For the seasonings I recommend sprinkling them evenly across the top of the stew. I changed the seasonings in the recipe slightly ( Crushed Rosemary, Parsley, Ground Cumin, Basil Leaves)  That should do it! I hope you enjoy your stew this was. Just a quick toss up I threw together on the spot.

A definite winner! I didn't have cornstarch, but I used flour, and keeping the comments in mind, I used a lot. I also put the beef chunks in a bag with flour, flavored with Penzey's  zata'ar and roasted garlic spices. I added a splash of wine to the liquid with some Worcestershire sauce. text:
Make like chuck. 1/4 cup flour, tsp onion powder garlic salt, 1/2 tsp pepper.  Coat meat and cook in french oven high heat to sear flavor in.  1/2 cup red wine, 4 cups beef stock, rosemary and thyme and simmer covered for an hour.  Then carrot, onion, celery, potato plus 2 more cups water. Cooked for 1 hour and wasn't done yet. Add salt and pepper to taste. 
Made with venison very good.

This will be my non-crockpot go to stew - most wonderful!

text:
Delicious- WITH CHANGES! Used a little over a pound of high quality beef, and needed less than 3 TBS oil. Subbed 32 oz box of low sodium beef broth and 1/2 cup red wine for bullion and water. Don't like rosemary and omitted it. Sprinkled meat with onion powder, 1 generous tsp garlic powder and 1/2 tsp pepper. rolled meat in 1/4 c flour to cover well. Browned meat, added parsley brought to boil, covered and simmered an hour. Added about 6 baby potatos quartered, 1/2 chopped onion, 6 carrots and 2 celery chopped. Added 5 tsp cornstarch in equal water. Simmered 40 minutes, added another tsp cornstarch right into the pot and left top off last 10 minutes. Flavor so great, hard not to overeat!

text:
It amazes me how many people will state "I followed the recipe exactly, but..." and then will proceed to list 15 different additions they chose -- EXCUSE ME but that is NOT following the recipe...that's creating your own recipe! Be fair to the original recipe poster (and the rest of us beginner cooks who rely heavily on these ratings) and rate the recipe as it is written so we can tell if it's truly a great recipe or not.  Now on to my review -- this was a pretty simple recipe to follow. I did have to add extra water (which is likely a result of variations in stoves/elevations, etc.) Overall I was happy with the taste and the way it turned out.  I think the next time I make it I will increase the rosemary (just to suit my individual taste) but honestly this is good as written.  I am single and like the fact that it makes enough for me so not have to worry about lunch/dinner for an entire week!!!

None
text:
This was great! I agree that it needs more flavor, which could be from me using beef stock instead of bouillon and water. I threw the beef with 1/4 cup flour, a teaspoon garlic salt, a teaspoon onion powder, and half a teaspoon pepper before I browned it which definitely added flavor and helped the broth thicken. I ended up adding about 1.5 teaspoons salt as well as a packet of beefy onion soup mix, and cooked it around three hours. Without this I don't think it would have been as flavorful, which is why I deducted a star. With my changes it was thick, beefy, hearty, and everything a beef stew should be!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I seasoned with 2 tsps of basil, 2 tsps of parsley, and 2 tsps of rosemary. I seasoned salt and pepper to taste. I took the advice of another user and used 1 tblsp of A1 Sauce and 1 tblsp of Worsteiner. I thickened the stew with a corn starch and flour mixture. Adding water to the stew takes away from the flavor. Use beef broth instead! I also leave out the beef cube because I don't like a lot of salt. I boil a cup of egg noddles on the side and serve add them to the soup, one bowl at a time ( I let guests add them if they want and the amount of the noddles they desire) Overall, the stew was really good! I have it made so many times and every time is tastes amazing!

This was delicious however I omitted the green beans and mushrooms as my family won't eat them. I also used 2 cups of red wine  and used them to deglaze the pan after i seared the beef and it made for an incredible rich flavor.  After deglazing the pan I added the bay leaf and seasonings and added oregano as well. I also added some smoked paprika to the flour when I coated the beef cubes.
I truly feel making these changes made all the difference.
Next time I will add the mushrooms since I love them and feel they would have added to the dish.

text:
Delicious and I did a double batch to have some later this week.  I made most of the changes suggested in other reviews - coating the meat with a seasoned flour, adding the red wine.  I sautéed my meat with the onion, skipped the celery and added a bag of frozen peas instead.  I cut large carrot chunks and used petite red potatoes, quartered or halved.  I let it simmer all afternoon and neither were mushy.  I used the broth (a little thickened from the flour and deglazing) with a 1/4 c of cornstarch to thicken it and it worked perfectly.

text:
If you've read through the reviews this far, stop and just make this stew!  One of the best stews I've made or eaten. I followed the recipe with a few minor changes based on other reviews.  I did coat the meat with flour (1/4 cup), garlic powder (1/2tsp.)and Montreal steak seasoning (1/2 tsp.). I also brushed it with kitchen bouquet browning sauce to give it a nice color.  After browning meat, I deglazed the pan with some water and couple Tblsp of sherry vinegar ( didn't have red wine on hand).  Next time I would add some more of the veggies but that's a personal preference. The rosemary really makes this a hearty comforting dish!

I love this recipe but I spice it up a bit. When I add the beef bouillon water solution I add three chopped red peppers, 3 jalapeños, and a red onion and then continue the recipe as normal except I do add 5 teaspoons of corn starch to thicken the stew compared to the 2 teaspoons the original recipe calls for. I'd recommend to try this if any one loves stew and spicy food.

The beef just fell apart, however I did cook it for about 5 hours! So delicious, such a great recipe.

text:
This has become my go-to recipe for Beef Stew.  My family loves it, and the flavor is even better as leftovers on day two.  I increase the beef to 3 lbs., increase the beef bouillon to 10 cubes, and double all the spices (rosemary, pepper, parsley).  I also use more cornstarch for a thicker stew.  It's fantastic.  Nothing better than a bowl of this stew and some crusty french bread on a cold winter night.

Display Name:
Janice Davidson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1903436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this beef stew recipe tonight for the first time for my husband and I.  I followed the recipe as it sounded very good as is.  The very slight extra I did do was to add some salt & pepper to the beef when it was browning.  As it was for only the two of us I did cut the recipe in half but still added a fair amount of carrots (5 small)  and two large potatoes, three small onions as they were very small and a couple of large celery sticks as we love the veggies in the stew!   I did read several reviews that said they added worcestershire, A1 steak sauce, paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, etc., but you certainly don't need all that.  With adding all of those flavors you wouldn't taste the beef and those delicious vegetables!  I used the Knorr's beef bouillon in the little pot to boiled water for the beef broth instead of those salty bouillon cubes and it was delicious.  Just before serving I added a very light dusting of salt & pepper to the stew and served with a kaiser roll.  My husband said it was absolutely delicious and I have to agree with him!  YUMMMY!!!  Thank you so much for sharing this recipe!  It is a keeper, for sure!!!  :)

I liked it alright as is and honestly review it as a 3 but the second time I made it I changed it up a bit and it made a much better stew. I still use this as my base recipe. 

 My changes : I  added a couple spoonfuls of tomato paste, a cup of frozen corn, TRIPLED the cornstarch  (I like thick strew) used chicken broth instead of the water and bouillon. I also used a bag of baby carrots, mainly cause it's easier to just dump in the pot :p those changes made it a 5 star recipe for me :)

This was fantastic but I did make some changes. I did not use rosemary, and instead substituted Italian seasoning. I used garlic powder as well. Instead of using regular carrots I chopped baby carrots into several pieces. Instead of using a whole onion I used half. I used the water and bouillon but I also added beef stock as needed throughout the cooking process when it looked like more liquid needed to be added. I also used Worcestershire sauce liberally twice: once when I added the vegetables and again when i was almost done but to taste. I did not add salt because the salt in the bouillon was enough. I did like others said and use more cornstarch than in the recipe.

Really good! I followed the recipe for the most part and used some tips from other reviewers. I dusted the beef in flour, garlic, and pepper before browning. (I do that with roast too.) I added extra carrots and used one less celery stalk (doesn't matter, we just like carrots more and celery not so much). I also added 1/2 cup of red wine and one tbsp. of worscheshire (sp).  Turned out fantastic! I put it in my favorites. Thanks!

P.S. - I cooked the onions in the first hour with the beef, then I added the carrots alone for about 20 minutes before I added the potatoes.

text:
Perfect stew on a cool Fall night!  Instead of using cornstarch to thicken I lightly dredged the meat in 1/4 cup flour seasoned with salt and pepper and seared the the meat in the oil.  I then used the broth to scrape up the brown bits.  As the stew cooked, the flour perfectly thickened the broth so a cornstarch slurry wasn't used.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I was looking for a quick and simple beef stew recipe and I found it.  I made a few small changes but all in all this was a great little recipe.  I didn't use the bullion cubes. I opted to lightly salt and pepper my meat after patting it dry and I used 4 cups of unsalted beef stock. I also added 3 tablespoons of red wine vinegar with the fourth cup of stock in place of the wine.  I don't drink and I find it difficult to buy a bottle of wine for one recipe, so I found this to be a good substitute.  The meat was tender and the veggies cooked up great.  Also the sauce was just right with the cornstarch add in. Very filling.  Next time I'll be doubling the recipe.  YUMO!!

Jan Corn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1721068.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
In my experience, the key to tender meat is long, slow simmering. I kept mine simmer at least 2 hours, at a bare simmer. I used beef stock instead of water or cubes, although I did make it with cubes once and it was still yummy. .  Because I cook stews so that they are filled with veggies, I did adjust those by sight and taste, adding at least  2 more carrots and celery and potatoes.

I consider this a personal preference since vegetables can differ in size.. The broth tastes wonderful and some might prefer a less thick stew.

 I also added more Rosemary because mine was not brand new so I wanted the herb to be more obvious. When chopping celery, I always chop some leaves for the added taste. Again, a personal preference. 

I am sure the stew would be wonderful without any tweaks.
Review:

5

text:
First time ever making stew. Didn't know how to approach but this was one of the recipes that caught me and gave me direction. I made changes from other comments. I used flour in a bag with a Tsp onion powder, garlic powder and pepper and shake the meat up in there. Nice and coated added flavor. Browned them all up in a separate pan. Meanwhile the pot I put olive oil in and added the chopped onion, broke them down a little and started adding the meats and stock, spices and veggies. Brought to boil and simmered...I will take out rosemary next time, not a fan. Added a shot of some good red wine. I used flour to thicken rather than starch. Potatos got enough as it is. Also added a Tbs of worshershire, A-1 and ketchup. It sat and sat and came out excellent, will definitely have a peppery taste. Pregnant girlfriend devoured it!!!!!!

country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time today.  Made the receipe based on others suggestions by doing the following:  mixed 1/4 cup of flour, 1 tsp. of onion powder and garlic powder with 1/4 tsp. of pepper in a ziploc bag and added stew meat and shook to cover.  I also added 1 tbls. of ea. A-1, ketchup, and Worcestershire sauce with 1/4 cup of Marsala wine before adding the cornstarch mixture to the liquid.  I also added 5 times the cornstarch mixture to get a thicker gravy.

This receipe is by far the best beef stew I have ever tasted.  I will only be using this receipe in the future.  So yummy and I am not really a beef stew lover, but I am now.  Thanks for all of the suggestions only enhances the flavors a of the original receipe!!!

This turned out to be a fantastic stew, however a head's up that when halving the quantity to 5, it changes 4 cups of water to 1 tsp of water, which is not nearly enough.

country:
None
text:
Even my kids loved this recipe!  I might even try it with venison next time, instead of beef.  This time I used top sirloin 1 inch cubes, coated in a mixture of 1/4 c. flour, 2 tsp garlic powder, 2 tsp onion powder (shake it up in a ziploc baggy).  Also added 1/2 cup red wine to the beef broth.   After adding all the veggies, my hubby tried it and said it was bland and needed a little something, so I added the following:  1 -8oz can tomato sauce, 2 TBS minced garlic, 2 TBS worcesteshire, 1 TBS brown sugar, 1 pkg dry onion soup mix.  Now it's FABULOUS!  Love it!

Not bad. I like my food more heavily seasoned than some people, so I made a few changes: doubled the amount of pepper, rolled the cubed beef in seasoned salt and meat tenderizer before cooking, substituted a cup of wine for one of the cups of water, and used flour instead of corn starch. I also used a handful of pearl onions instead of chopping a regular onion.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe and I have made many times over the last few years.  However, I make it over the top by first coating my meat with flour seasoned with salt, pepper, garlic and onion powder.  I don't use bullion personally so I can afford to add some salt to the seasoned flour.  I use Better than Bullion in water to make 4 cups worth.  After browning the meat in batches in a dutch oven, I add in the broth to deglaze all the goodness stuck to the bottom and then add back in the meat.  I then add in a few tablespoons of each Worcestershire and A1 sauce.  I follow the rest of the recipe.  Always a great, great meal!  Thank you for this recipe!

text:
This was delicious but I did tweak based on reviews. I used 5 pounds of beef so I had to double ingredients and adjust a little. I shook the meat with 1/2 cup flour, 1/2 tsp each of garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper before browning. I added 1 cup red wine, 1 can beef broth, and 2 tbsp each of ketchup, A1, and Worcestershire sauce to the base. And I didn't really measure the veggies. Just added enough to look right. The potatoes I used are baby yellows so they don't get mushy. So tasty!

text:
I am a retired chef so had to monkey with the recipe, sorry. Made it yesterday as written for myself, the proportions are excellent and the seasoning is really good except for the salt. Today I made it for company and made the following 3 changes. #1 I added garlic  ( I like garlic and it is really good for you) #2 when I sautéed the meat in olive oil I added the vegetables and sautéed them as well. (it is a flavor thing) #3 and most important I did not use bullion cubes. To much sodium for an old guy like me. I used beef stock I made. (Swanson low sodium would work as well) I will make it again, company loved it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe but, of course like most cooks I made changes to make this recipe my own. However, I did need this recipe as a guide and appreciate the post.

OLIVE OIL: I use California  (not Italian -no guarantee it is even olive oil as of 2016) pure virgin olive oil instead of vegetable oil. Less olive oil is needed.

LIQUIDS: Instead of four cups of water I used 2 cups of 100% all-natural beef broth (Swanson's  when I don't have mine on hand), 1/2 cup of red wine and 1 & 1/2 cups water.

NO bouillon cubes.

GARLIC! 2-3  Garlic cloves, minced, depending  on size and individual preference. I add to the onions.

Display Name:
Charlotte

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3543825.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT stew! I've made it twice now. Per others advice, I put 1/4 c of flour, a few  dashes of onion salt (I did not have onion powder on hand) a few dashes of garlic powder and pepper in a gallon bag and shook it up with the meat then browned the meat with seasonings in olive oil. For extra spices per others advice, I added a few tbsp of ketchup, a few dashes of Worcestershire, and a few dashes of tobasco sauce. Really made a good flavor! I didn't have the time to let the beef bollian water simmer for an hour and the meat simmers or an hour. I just made it and threw it all together and it still was delicious and meat tender. I also used  about 10-12 little potatoes (it's what I had on hand)instead of the normal size russet potatoes. They softened in great time...using those I also don't have to peel... Just a matter of preference.  Will definitely be using this recipe!

text:
This stew is great. I made it several times in durch owen and my family loves it. Last time I decided to try slow cooker. I did not  brown meat on a pan, I just put all the ingredients into the crockpot except cornstarch, set temperature to high level and let it cook for four hours. After that I added cornstarch dissolved in water, poured it into crockpot and cooked one more hour on high level. The result was even better than from dutch owen :-)

country:

text:
in a bag I put 1/4 cup flour, teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder. 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Put the stew meat in, and shook it up baby! Then I cooked it up in my ( cast iron ) dutch oven and seared in those flavors. This really put some great flavor on that meat and the yummy bits stuck to the bottom of the cast iron pan easily came off during the deglazing with the liquids. I didn't cut back on any liquids..actually you will probably want to add more towards the middle-end of the cooking time. I used 1/2 cup of red wine during the deglazing with the other liquids. I thought it needed more vegetables since I made this recipe 2 weeks ago staying true to the recipe..but this time when I did it, I added an extra ( 1 more carrot, celery, potato ) I added 1/2 of an extra onion. I also took the advise of another reviewer and added 1 tblspn each of ketchup, A-1 sauce, and wistersire sauce that really gave it some full-bodied flavor. I trippled the amount of cornstarch as other people suggested to make it thicker
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-03-22T14:02:33.337
helpfulCount:
0

GeeNance

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my son's birthday. At his request I reduced the celery and added parsnips. I'm generally not a parsnips fan, but they were great in this stew.

Before browning, I put the beef in a large ziplock bag and tossed it with a mixture of cornstarch, pepper, salt, garlic powder, onion powder and a dash of Montreal steak spice.

During cooking I added a few dashes of Worchestershire sauce for a bit of extra depth/zip.

20 minutes before end of cooking I added small balls of biscuit dough to the top of the simmering stew. And put the lid back on the pot.  The biscuits turned out great and made the stew seem a bit fancier.

To make the biscuit dough I simply combined:  1 ½ cups self-raising flour; ½ tsp garlic powder; ¼ cup shortening; ½ cup shredded Tex-Mex cheese; ? cup milk.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
This stew is great and my family loves it.  It is very easy to make and the aroma in the house draws everyone to the kitchen.  It has become on of our favorite dinners that everyone loves.  The only change I made was that instead of using beef bouillions that are salty, I used a low sodium box of beef broth.  The first few times I tried reducing the amount of bouillons, but it was still too salty.
I served the beef stew over white or brown rice and it is delicious comfort food for cold winters.

text:
A-MAZING!  I also served it in the Italian Bread Bowls (recipe on AR, from Kerri Skrudland - which are fantastic!).  Kids and adults alike gobbled it up. I did the meat in a dutch oven (floured/seasoned based on other reviews), transferred it into a crockpot (with  2c beef broth). I deglazed the dutch oven with 1 1/2c red wine, and transferred everything over to the slow cooker. I cooked it on high for one hour, added the vegetables, and cooked on high for 4 hours. I basically doubled the recipe, using 3lb of stew meat, and enough veggies to make me happy!  Absolutely a keeper!

userID:
5344556
Display Name:
dicket
