photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here is what I did. in a bag I put 1/4 cup flour, teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder. 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Put the stew meat in, and shook it up baby! Then I cooked it up in my ( cast iron ) dutch oven and seared in those flavors. This really put some great flavor on that meat and the yummy bits stuck to the bottom of the cast iron pan easily came off during the deglazing with the liquids. I didn't cut back on any liquids.. actually you will probably want to add more towards the middle-end of the cooking time. I used 1/2 cup of red wine during the deglazing with the other liquids. I thought it needed more vegetables since I made this recipe 2 weeks ago staying true to the recipe, but this time when I did it, I added an extra ( 1 more carrot, celery, potato ) I added 1/2 of an extra onion. I also took the advise of another reviewer and added 1 tblspn each of ketchup, A-1 sauce, and wistersire sauce that really gave it some full-bodied flavor...Wow!! Served it up to my family with some home made southern style buttermilk biscuits...mmm, mmm, good delicious!! As my Dad also said "There ought to be a law against cooking this good!"

text:
Wonderful!  Instead of beef stew meat, I picked up a sirloin steak on sale and then just browned the steak whole.  Added the seasonings and also added garlic powered and onion powder.  After an hour, added the potatoes (about 6), over a half of a large bag of baby carrots, celery and onion.  Also took the suggestion of others, added 1t. Of ketchup, Worcestershire sauce, and A-1 sauce at this point.  I added a little more water to cover the vegetables.   After the vegetables simmered for an hour, I shredded the meat and I actually took a masher and mashed the vegetables to make it more of a soup.  Very good, will make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Instead of adding cornstarch, follow Chuck's suggestions.  My cooking time is a bit different.  I cook down the stew meat mixture for 1 1/2 hours and then add vegetables and cook for an additional 45 minutes.  I use 2 bay leaves and a teaspoon of paprika and my magic ingredients?  Stir in 1 Tablespoon of sugar with added water to cover the veggies. After you add the vegetables add a generous squeeze of lemon juice.  The lemon juice perks up the vegetables.  I don't use ketchup and use two cloves of fresh minced garlic with the meat mix and Worcestershire sauce to perk up the meat.  Thanks to you both for posting.  This just resurrected childhood memories and tastes!

text:
This was by far the best beef stew I have ever made! I followed the recipe to a T except I added 2 tablespoons of ketchup and a tablespoon of  worcester sauce before I simmered the broth and I used 2 liquid boxes of beef stock  in stead of the beef bullion dissolved in water. My fiancé is allergic to MSG  and it was in every bullion I have found. Its crazy how easy this is to make and how delicious it is! This recipe is now a staple in my house!

text:
This recipe is great!!! I read the reviews before I made it and tweaked some things. 1) I added 5 bullion cubes b/c some others had said that it could be slightly bland. I didn't replace the water with any wines b/c my mother in law doesn't tolerate any "booze" in her kitchen. So adding the extra cube was great! Very flavorful! 2) I skipped the corn starch b/c I tend to like more brothy stews. 3) I added mushrooms just for some more veggie variety. But over all this is a great recipe!!! I will definitely hold this one in my arsenal!

I hate people that change the recipe and then rate it.  I am sure it would be wonderful as written but I did make some changes.  I only used one bouillon cube with 4 cups of water.  I also added a carton of low sodium vegetable stock because that is what I had on hand.  I also added rutabaga that was cubed about 2 cups it has a sweet taste.  In the last half hour I added a bag of mixed veggies. I added some kitchen bouquet for flavor and rich color.  I got 20 good size servings.  I did put some in the freezer.  Yum!

userID:

Display Name:
Erin Sheldon
isPro:

followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We've made this many times and used many of the suggestions from the reviews as well as following the recipe exactly. Following the recipe exactly, I consider this a four star. Following some of the suggestions in the reviews, this becomes the best stew I've ever made. Its even better when we coat the meat pieces in flour and seasonings before browning them. I like it best when I add my onions just after I've browned the meat, and cook them up a bit in the meat juices before adding the rest of the broth. We also really like the suggestion to substitute some red wine for some of the broth/bouillon. I use Better than Bouillon, which is excellent. I like to substitute red pepper flakes for black pepper and I grind my salt, red pepper flakes, rosemary, and often oregano before adding these to the stew because I find the herbs are most flavourful that way. This is a flexible recipe and good with all kinds of additional vegetables or with other vegetables substituted.

Display Name:
Missy Thoensen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1559053.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the basic instructions searing the stew meat in olive oil, then added beef broth vs the bullion. I added a clove of minced garlic to the olive oil. Also, I added about a tsp of ground pepper and two tsp of salt and worked it into the raw stew meat before searing in oil.  Once I simmered the beef for an hour, I added the vegetables. But I chose to put ground pepper, 1/4 tsp of rosemary and a bay leaf for my seasonings along with the veggies. I added fresh sweet corn from the cob. I steamed two cobs until just cooked, then cut the corn off the cob. That way, the corn would be crunchy and the sweetness would stay intact. At the end, I had to add about a 1/4 of a cup of flour dissolved in water to thicken the broth.

I made a bunch of changes based on all the previous reviews, and this version was killer:  1.  flour/pepper/salt and then sear the beef.  deglaze pot with 1 cup red wine (or whatever I had on hand) - 
- 1 whole onion, chopped
- 1/2 lb mushrooms - a few shakes of garlic powder.  - frozen mixed veg (1/2 cup or whatever I had) - 1 tbsp Worstershire, 1 tbsp ketchup - and the cornstarch slurry (mix the cornstarch with cold water then take to a boil then continue cooking.  IT WAS AMAZING.

text:
This turned out great! I did as some other reviews suggested and coated the beef with a mixture of flour and spices prior to browning. I also swapped 1/2 cup of water for 1/2 cup of red wine and doubled the amount of cornstarch because we like a thicker sauce. The veggies were cooked perfectly and the meat was so tender. Next time I'll add some fresh mushrooms as well.

text:
I made a few of the changes Chuck suggested and a few changes of my own. I added garlic, sage and oregano to the spices. I also bought a pre-tenderized Outside Round Roast, that was on sale, and cubed it. It was 3 pounds. It melted in your mouth. I prefer this way to buying stewing beef which can be fatty.

I usually make my stews in the crockpot but I needed to make more than mine will hold. 
The stovetop method with my large pot worked great.

Result... PLEASE make this again mom. This is the best you've ever made.

Thanks so much for sharing this recipe. :) :)

userID:
235527
Display Name:
TechieMommie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hearty beef stew.  Notes for self: flour w/s&p and dredge 1lb boneless short ribs, trimmed to 1 - 2 in pieces  Sear in dutch oven with 1 tbl olive oil.  Add two cloves garlic minced, at end of sear.  Add beef broth to cover (about 3c), scraping bits from bottom/side.  Add 1/2 tsp Better than Bouillion Roasted Beef.  Boil, then reduce to simmer.  Cover and cook for 1 hr (at 30min, ck liquid and stir).  Add red potatoes, carrots and celery, cook for 30min.  Stir, adding liquid as necessary.   Cook for 15 - 30min more.  Thickened enough by dredging flour, no cornstarch needed.
Review:

4

userID:
9100201
Display Name:
kdaws
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
112
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The hubs wanted stew! I followed many of the reviewers who put flour, garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper in a bag with the meat and then shook it up. I did not use any salt at all. I then browned the meat in Marsala wine. Next added two cups of water mixed with bouillon granules and brought the meat to a boil. Then added the rosemary and parsley and veggies (minus celery) without waiting the hour. Return to boil. Next added a handful of uncooked barley and some coconut milk. Put the lid on and turned down to simmer for one hour. When it had about 15 minutes left, I added additional coconut milk and Worcestershire sauce to taste. Served with warm rolls. No need for cornstarch to thicken, as I used less liquid to begin with. Husband loved it!!!! I did too! Next time I think I will add mushrooms and green beans. Definitely will be adding this to our winter rotation.

This beef stew! Its really good. I basically followed the recipe as written, I just added more corn starch. I also added the little 'dressing' to it of 1Tbsp Ketchup, Worcestershire and A1 respectively that another reviewer suggested. I mixed this into the cornstarch and water blend for easy distribution.

text:
Wonderful stew!  Adding it to the "family recipes" for sure!  I followed all of the instructions above and took some notes from others for this recipe.  I added one more carrot, celery stalk, potato (Yukon gold), and half of a small onion.  I also used beef broth instead of boullion (one large carton, plus 1 can) so that it wouldn't be too salty.  I seasoned the beef with garlic powder on one side and pepper on the other before searing, and added 1 tbsp. each of ketchup, A-1, and Worcestershire.  Followed directions as stated, and thickened with Wondra instead of cornstarch as I just prefer that for thickening.

userID:
13221927
Display Name:
wisecrone
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
430
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's actually a good recipe.  I'm just old-fasioned, and have made stove-top stew almost all of my life (73 yrs.).  I put the pieces of meat (we use venison or elk because we have it) in a gallon bag with flour, salt and pepper to taste and shake it so every piece is covered.  Then I brown the meat in olive oil, put the seasonings over the meat and add chopped onion and garlic to taste turning the meat so it gets browned evenly.  I also, half way through the browning pour in a decent (not cooking wine) red wine...enough to half-way cover the meat, and finish the browning with a cover over the pot, still stirring now and then.  To the now browned meat, I add liquid bullion and water, about half and half, to about two inches above the meat being sure to stir up all of the good stuff in the bottom of the pot.  Bring to a boil, turn down to a good simmer, add the carrots, and a teaspoon (or to your choice) of celery salt (we don't like celery in dishes, just the taste), cover and simmer slowly (checking for liquid level from time to time and stirring) until carrots are almost to your tenderness choice, and then add potatoes, and if called for, more bullion and/or red wine.  Simmer covered until potatoes and carrots are done to your liking.  At this point, you can thicken your juices with flour (my preference) or cornstarch and water or bullion, stirring often.  I often make stew a day ahead as the tastes meld overnight and it's much richer.  I also, on occasion add Chinese Five S
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2015-10-05T01:01:12.657
helpfulCount:

Thanks, your recipe made me want to make this now that fall is here. Use chuck beef for best results.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my gosh. This stew was amazing. Set serving size to 14.  Used about 2 1/2 lbs beef a cut above stew beef. Used 1/2 cup of flour and 2 tsp onion and garlic powder and 1 tsp pepper to coat beef. Browned. Used 1 cup sweet red wine to deglaze.  Added 4 2/3 cups beef broth. And dry parsley and Rosemary. 1 tbsp A-1 and wistershire sauces. Simmered 1 hour. Added more than recommended celery, carrots and red potatoes, onion and simmered another hour. Added 2 tsp to small amount of cold water and added to stew. Amazing! Served with whole grain bread from the bakery.

text:
Love all the ingredients but modified it by using moose meat and floured the meat first with some seasoned flour.  I used Montreal steak seasoning for some zip. Browned the meat and added minced fresh garlic just before adding the liquids. I used 4 cups of beef broth and 1/2 cup red wine for liquids plus a splash or two or more of Worsestershire sauce. The stew was delicious. A define do-again.

text:
Took the advice of others and shook the meat first in a baggie filled with 1/4 cup of flour and some seasonings (pepper, garlic salt, and chicago style rub).  Didnt have any celery, so i cooked it without.  I didnt seem to miss it.  I was also out of rosemary :( but i added some other good spices, included "slap your mama", and the flavor was delicious.  I think i will add portabella mushrooms next time and more meat.  Because of the flour, i didnt add the corn starch, but if you wanted it thicker you could.  i might try adding some wine next time too :)  It was a surprisingly good stew for such simple ingredients.  i think i prefer this over my crock pot version :)

text:
My husband stated that this was the best stew he has ever eaten. 

After reading reviews, i made the following changes.....used 2 cups water and 2 cups red cooking wine. I added a couple splashes of Worcestershire sauce. I used 4 red potatoes (unpeeled) and I did use more cornstarch as was recommended.  I opted to cook this in my dutch oven at a very low temp until the last 20 minutes, making my cook time about 5 hours. 
I will make this again.

text:
What a delicious recipe. I am new to cooking and this recipe couldn't have been simpler. My husband and daughter love it. Very easy and you don't really have to keep an eye on it. I did change a little bit of the recipe. Right before you cook the meat I did what another reviewer said and put the meat in a bag with 1/4 flour added a teaspoon of garlic and onion. powder with half a teaspoon of pepper. Shaking it all up, it smells amazing. Then you fry it in oil to really capture those flavors in the meat. As for the bouillon cubes, for me they never really dissolve like I wanted them to so I purchased the beef powder bouillon and it tastes amazing. Delicious. One of my favorite recipes from this site.

text:
Made this tonight, with no changes. I used Herb Ox brand bouillon w/ no MSG (but WITH sodium), and the stew still tasted under-seasoned. I needed to add a little salt and a dash of Worchester at the table to keep it from tasting so bland. If you serve it with a salty biscuit and salted butter (as I did), you the salt in those other foods will round out each mouthful. Otherwise, good recipe for someone watching his/her sodium intake.

Placed the quarter cabbage on the top of the stew and let the stew cook the cabbage, gently. Delicious!!!

text:
I used this recipe as a base but I made a few changes (I always do).
I sauteed my onions & celery first in the vegetable oil removed them and set to the side. Then I seasoned and flour the meat n browned n the pan. Then I added the bouillon cubes n water n simmered for a minute till meat looked almost done scraping the bottom of dutch oven pot to get all the flour n goodness. I then placed my baby carrots n potatoes in and placed in the oven and let it cook slow.. The meat was so tender and the gravy was the right thickness.... its a keeper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm rating this 5 stars because it tastes great and is very simple.  We just upscaled this recipe to feed about 125 servings plus added more water and boullion to give us enough extra gravy to stretch further if need be.  It came out great even at that scale and was simple enough to prepare for such a large crowd.  The only thing we had to be careful of as we increased our gravy amount was making sure the saltiness of the boullion cube didn't take over, but we found it didn't in our case.  Our meat was nice and tender but we did cook the stew a lot longer than the recipe due to the extra large pots and the need to get it started early in the day.  Other than that the proportions of ingredients and seasonings and everything else was per the recipe (although we did chop the celery into smaller pieces, about 1/2 inch).  For at home, I might add in some extra veggies of different sorts for a change but I found the seasoning to be really good and we got rave reviews at our event.

I only had 1lb of beef defrosted, so I adjusted the recipe a bit. Coated in flour, garlic powder, parsley, rosemary and pepper to fast fry, then added a little more pepper, rosemary and parsley with 2c broth and 1/2c red wine. After an hour, added in the chopped potatoes, and simmered in low for another 1 1/2 hrs, then added in some frozen mixed veg for the last half hr (no carrots or celery in the house ATM).

text:
I didn't read reviews before trying it out. I made some of my own modifications based on ingredients at hand and previous stew experience. It turned out to be a very good, likeable stew but didn't leave me raving. I didn't have bouillon so used chicken broth instead, 1/4 cup wine, bay leaves, thyme, Worcestershire sauce. I was intrigued by the lack of browning with flour, but I think next time I will use seasoned flour to brown and deglaze as many people have suggested. Definitely needs garlic and mine needed salt since I wasn't using bouillon.  It's a good base stew recipe to work from I think, easy to follow and easy to modify

userID:
206113
Display Name:
PUCCI
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
145
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/101064.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made the stew in a pressure cooker.  First brown meat with a little oil and deglaze with 1/2 cup wine.  Replace bullion with 2 cans of beef stock and add 2 tablespoons of tomato paste.  Put everything else in pressure cooker except corn starch for 15 minutes and then release pressure slowly. Open top add about 1/2 cup peas and 2 tablespoons of corn starch after mixing with some water to dissolve as a thickening agent. Add salt and pepper to taste and put back on stove top.  Turn on pressure cooker for five more minutes and again slow release pressure. If the meat or veggies should not be done to your liking just increase or decrease cook time by a minute or more. Be sure to have some Italian bread for dipping in the sauce.
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:

text:
Followed the recipe almost as is, except added more seasonings namely garlic powder, onion powder, salt, paprika and extra dried parsley. Had to skip on the rosemary since I didn't have any but it still turned out great. I recommend adding the carrots and potatoes just for the last 40 min so they're not too smushy. Ate it over white basmati rice topped with crushed red pepper. Super satisfying and cooked to perfection! Thank you for a great recipe.

text:
My search for THE beef stew has ended. I used this as a basis for the stew I ended up making. I started it with mirepoix (mixture of diced carrots , onions and celery), used beef broth instead. I also browned the meat first. Added bay leaves and half a cup of red wine. I also added canned whole plum tomatoes (not the juice) towards the end.  After it was done and cooled, I let it sit in the fridge overnight to let the flavors deepen. It was great, my 3 year old was mopping up the sauce with bread.

text:
As is the recipe is good.  I usually make a slow cooker beef stew with stout and lots of root veggies.  I prep it the night before and just pop it into the slow cooker in the morning.  Well I forgot and I'd already promised my family beef stew so I tried this one.  The really liked it but said it needed a few things like garlic, a little thyme and of course, the stout.  Because we have a corn allergy and we are also Celiac, I thicken stews with instant potato flakes.  Just a 1/2 cup was perfect for the thickness we were looking for.  Try it.

text:
Awesome! I made the following changes: halved the recipe. Didn't use celery. Added fresh green beans, a clove of garlic, and a cup of red wine. Didn't have rosemary or beef bullion cubes on hand so used basil and chicken bullion. Had planned on starting to cook early then something came up so I chopped all the veggies and threw them in the micro steamer for about 8-9 min. Then put them in with the beef cubes and cooked for one hour. Turned out so good! I'm sure the meat would have been more tender if I'd had more time but it was still great. Served with homemade red skinned mashed potatoes and yeast rolls. Yum-my!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3717645.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy yumminess! This was really good. I did take the advice of a few other reviewers. 

Here’s what I did: 
Put 1/4 cup flour in bag along with 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 tsp onion powder & 1/2 tsp pepper.
Put meat in and shook it up. I then seared the meat in a pot then scraped off the bits at the bottom while adding the liquid (I added about ½-1 additional cup of water towards the middle/end of cooking).
You will probably want to add more liquid towards the middle/end of the cooking time, I added about ½-1 additional cup of water. Lastly, I added 1 tbsp ketchup & Worcestershire. So much flavor! 

My husband is a super picky eater and he really enjoyed this stew.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was great! I just did some things differently. I seasoned my meat with worshire sauce, garlic powder, black pepper, cayenne pepper, celery seeds, dried chives, parley, chopped onions and adobo. I let the meat sit for about 3-4 hrs. Then I browned the meat in olive oil, allowed it to make it's own water, place maybe a cup full more, a pinch of dry rosemary, 2 bay leaves and covered. After simmering for an hour I put more onions and a couple of cubed potatoes in. At the last 30 mins I added chopped green and red peppers along with frozen corn, green beans and carrot mix, along with corn starch. It turned out excellent!!!!!!

Very tasty and easy!!  I did make a few changes and added garlic instead of rosemary and put in just a pinch of dried parsley. I also added a few bayleaves. I didnt have cornstarch on hand so i used flour instead.  I started with 1Tbsp dissolved in water and gradually added it in.  I did find tht it was too thin for my liking, so i did another Tbsp of flour dissolved in water.  I let it simmer for a few minutes and it was perfect!!

text:
Love reading the comments.  Everyone gives it a 5 star rating and then tells about all the changes.  For starters, we never use bouillon cubes.  I just used water to deglaze the pan and added a shake of Worcestershire sauce.  This turned out just fine.  Actually, this is pretty much the recipe I use for stew all the time, but I mostly make it with lamb.  One can also add parsnips or turnips, if desired.  But potatoes, onions, carrots and celery are required at a minimum.  I would never add garlic to this.  Good with a salad and some fresh baked bread or on noodles.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe, but I did dress it up just a little via some of the reviews. I tossed the meat in 1/4 cup flour with 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/4 teaspoon onion powder, and half of the black pepper (1/4 teaspoon); I browned it in 2 tablespoons oil (1 less than the recipe called for) and deglazed the pan with 1/2 cup red wine. I increased the potatoes to 6 medium (I used red ones with skin) and also increased the carrots to 6 medium. I added 2 bay leaves and a dried Japanese red pepper (with half of the seeds removed) along with the other dried herbs. I also increased the cornstarch to 1.5 tablespoons and left the lid off during the last 15 minutes, per the uploader's instructions; the added flour and potato also helped to thicken the final product, as did a little resting time. It turned out very nice and will be a definite repeat.

text:
Not fair, I embellished on this, and everyone loved it, so I'm sorry to rate it but wanted to add my 2 cents.

Added; McCormick Brown Gravy packet, McMormick Hearty Beef Stew packet,  used Chuck Roast, Season Salt, Meat Tenderizer, Liquid Smoke, A-1 sauce, onion powder, garlic powder, potatoes and veggies.  Put 1/4 C flour, seasoning salt, meat tenderizer, liquid smoke, salt and pepper in bag, shook it up the day before to marinate.  
Next time I'll increase the flour a little bit, although nobody else thought it needed it to be thicker.  I'm 60 and have never made stew before and am glad I did, it's probably the healthiest meal I've made all year and great for a winter meal.

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe warms the cockles of your heart! I added a about 6 Tbsp. of butter for smooth texture and also 3/4- 1 cup of green peppers for a mildly "hot" flavor.(Not spicy.)-- For a more soup-like quality (if you are not a stew-eater)just add more water and cover and simmer for awhile longer. I seasoned my meat while searing it and then added more seasoning to the water. I added more salt and pepper for stronger flavor and skipped the rosemary. -- Instead of bouillon I used stock. I find chicken stock over beef makes a nice interesting flavor. -- Egg noodles are delicious when boiled in the broth! (I find the medium size noodles hold the beefy flavor more than the larger sizes.) -- If you are averse to celery (I used 2 stalks instead of 4), just know that after boiling they taste like peas. But even if you don't eat them, ADD THEM to the pot! If makes a big difference in flavor.
Review:
Rating:
5

country:
None
text:
This was a good, classic beef stew. I added some garlic powder with the spices and needed more like a tablespoon of cornstarch to get it to a good thickness. Next time I think I would finely dice the onions and celery and sautee them in the oil ahead of browning the meat to develop some deeper flavor and because I don't like noticing the chunks of onion/celery in my stew. I think the meat could easily simmer for another hour before adding the vegetables if you want it fall-apart tender. As it was, it was just tender enough to cut with a fork but not quite as soft as I like it in stew.

text:
This was a good recipe to start with.  Here's what I added:  Used low sodium beef broth in place of bouillion cubes because there is too much sodium in cubes.  I heated the broth and added flour to thicken the gravy.  Also added 2 teaspoons of granulated garlic, and replaced the vegetable oil with extra virgin olive oil.  I also coated stew meat with flour and browned in dutch oven along with onion that I sliced instead of cubes.  I increased meat to 3 lbs and added another potato and three more carrots.  
Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
Made a few changes, but overall the taste was fabulous!  I coated the beef with a flour, garlic powder, onion powder and pepper mixture.  Then browned.  Took beef out and sautéed onions cut into thin rings.  Deglazed the pot with a little red wine and then added the beef back in along with 2 cans of beef broth and a can of water.  This way the onion becomes part of the broth and seasons the meat while cooking.  I followed the rest of the recipe as written, except that I added green beans about 15 min before the stew was finished cooking.  Very tasty with crusty bread!

text:
This was very good, but I have to dock it a star for being way too thin.  I ended up quadrupling the cornstarch slurry for a nice thick and hearty stew.  Also, I deglazed the pan with a splash of red wine after browning the meat, which I seasoned with garlic salt and pepper before cooking.  I also added halved garlic cloves to the veggies.  Will make again with my same changes!

text:
This is a good starter recipe for potato soup. The recipe allows room to adjust for one's tastes. I didn't feel it was a five star recipe as there is definitely room for improvement. But that's not to say the recipe itself wasn't great. It had a good meat to vegetable ratio, but there was a slight lack of flavor with the spices. I'm going to have to play around with different spices to get the flavor I'm looking for, or use other's suggestions and maybe add red wine or something.

text:
This was fine. I used a lot more rosemary, accidentally on purpose -- I used dried and thought there was just a little more than was called for in the jar, so I dumped it all, and in retrospect it looked like a lot more than needed but it tasted fine. The gravy part was also fine. This isn't a highly seasoned stew. I floured before searing, which probably helped thicken the gravy and certainly makes the meat taste better (and the gravy)...and if I had it to do over I'd replace a cup of water with a cup of dark red wine. I probably won't make this one again bc I make stew once a year every year forgetting that my DH doesn't actually like beef stew. Go figure. The baby and I liked it, though, thank you for sharing!

text:
It was good but not great. Although I must admit I am not a huge stew fan to begin with. My wife loved it. It had a bit too much rosemary flavor. So if I make it again, I would use a bit less rosemary and probably add some minced garlic. I was afraid it would be very salty with the 4 bouillon cubes but I didn't find it too salty at all. I also ended up about tripling the amount of corn starch and letting it cook with the lid off for about an additional hour to get it thickened up more.

text:
I just made this and it's DELICIOUS! My family, including a picky 4 year-old, loved it. I followed exactly except I seasoned the meat with 3 cloves fresh garlic, 1/2 teaspoon onion powder, 1/2 teaspoon black pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon ground red pepper. I also used 1 cup wine and 3 cups water instead of all 4 cups water. I doubled the corn starch but still wish it were thicker. I'll add more later. I also found there wasn't enough gravy so I'll probably add 2 cups more liquid next time. Great recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make a half recipe of this using 900 ml sodium reduced beef stock, usually Campbells, an equal am't of water, and a teaspoon of Better Than Bouillon. I add turnip and fresh green and yellow beans, if in season. 2 bay leaves go in with the stock.  After the browned meat simmers for 2 hours, I add the turnip first, and add each vegetable singly, a bit later, depending on the cooking time req'd for each veg. I thicken with a thick flour and water mix just before serving, blending the stock with a elec hand blender, grinding up some potato and carrot in the process. I'll try adding rosemary next batch.

This was a very good base recipe. I just added a few more things to it.  First of all, I had no white potatoes, so I added sweet potatoes which were white inside, (I don't know what kind they were).  I also added a can of diced tomatoes and a couple bay leaves and some frozen green beans. I first put the beef in a mixture of flour, salt and pepper, shook it in a plastic bag and then browned it in the oil. The rest I followed from the recipe. This was SO good!  My husband who loves his white potatoes liked the way this came out.  Yum!

Great recipe for cold rainy days like today!! Im not to much of a stew kinda gal but this recipe is great. text:
Love this recipe because it is sooooo easy. Although I made a few adjustments. I decided I wanted to make it a little spicy so I added two serrano peppers, which I partially regret cause now it is almost too spicy, so I'll probably just add 1 next time. Also, instead of parsley I used cilantro and since I didn't have cornstarch I used 4 teaspoons of flour with 4 teaspoons of water instead. Overall, great reciple, very easy and the outcome makes you want to make it again and again.

text:
Just finished eating this stew. Knowing others thought it was too thin, I added twice as much cornstarch and it was still very thin and bland.  So, I squirted in some ketchup and some Worcestershire and salt (we eat low salt but this needed it).  To thicken it I put in two packets of turkey gravy powder with the smallest amount of water possible. That thickened it and it tasted really pretty good. I'll make it again but take more advice from these ratings first. A good base.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  Did make a few changes.  As others did, I tossed the beef cubes in flour before browning in pan.  I used fresh rosemary because I had it on hand.  I also added 2 T tomato paste for flavor and thickening.  I added about 2 t worcestershire sauce.  I also added 1 clove garlic and 1 minced shallot as well as 1 T Italian seasoning to add flavor.  The recipe alone sounded too bland to me, but with these additions it was delicious.  Giving it a 5 because the main concept of this dish works really well.  At last 1/2 hour, I decided to add 1/2 cup each frozen peas and corn to add some color.  I cooked this on the stovetop, then kept it warm in a 250 F oven for about another hour which seemed to be perfect as I don't know that the original 2 hour cooking time was quite enough.

Absolutely, hands down best basic stew I've tried, and I know my comfort food - as both my wife and tailor will confirm.  After several tries and reading the reviews I've added only minor changes more for my taste, like adding the pepper and 3 cloves of garlic as the meat is searing, then adding Worcester (2 tbs),a splurch of ketchup (empirical term), and a teaspoon of Oregano while the meat simmers in the sauce.  I've also added large chunk mushrooms, quickly pan seared on high heat, and added 30 minutes after the other vegetables (depends on my mood).  Well Done Paula - Bravo

text:
Great!!  I wanted thicker gravy so I tripled the corn starch and water and followed the suggestions to flour the meat with 1/2 Cup flour, 1T garlic powder and the pepper, brown it and then add everything else including 1/2 cup red wine.  I also added another suggestion of 1T Ketchup, 1T Worcestershire Sauce and 1T A1 Steak sauce.  I cooked it a day ahead of time and it was YUMMY!!  This was all based on reading lots of the reviews and pulling out what everyone kept repeating.  Serve it with a crusty bread or biscuits to sop up all the gravy.

text:
I rated on the mobile app but wanted to comment. Delish!! I halved the recipe since I was cooking for 2. I also coated the stew meat with 1/4 cup flour, garlic powder and Costco Organic No Salt Seasoning and mixed it in a gallon baggie. I had extra flour when I poured the meat into the pan and it ended up being the perfect amount to thicken without adding more than the amount of cornstarch that was called for! I did add about 1/4 carton of veggie stock when I added the veggies as the liquid seemed a bit low. I used extra carrot and red potatoes (no celery, my bf doesnt like) and the veggies were cooked perfectly. Served with french bread for a perfect meal!

I am in the process of making this. I asked my husband to taste it for seasoning. He had this odd look on his face, then he told me it was great! He said he'd never had a stew that tasted like this one. He loves it! So do I. Before I put the meat in I did toss it in seasoned flour and seared. Since I did this I didn't need to add the cornstarch for thickening. I also used some white wine to get all the num-nums off the bottom of the pan I used to sear the meat. I sure will make this again!

I loved it. When I made it, I didn't have enough beef. My own fault, I only bought 1 lb... will remember more beef next time! I also substituted vegetable oil with olive oil, it's what I had at home. Next time, I think I will add some wine, too.

text:
Excellent "classic" beef stew! Not too much going on that distracts from the tastes of the meat and veggies. Minor adjustments based on others' suggestions: coated beef with seasoned flour prior to browning, added an extra carrot and potato, used fresh rosemary (but did not increase amt), and tripled cornstarch amt. I added a tsp each of Worcester sauce, A1 and ketchup, but I'll start with 1/2 tsp each next time and add more to taste. It was a little overpowering. I also added a little extra beef broth when adding the veggies. This is my new go-to beef stew recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This stew is excellent and very easy to make.  I doubled the vegetables, except for the potatos and I sweated the onions, celery and carrots with three chopped cloves of garlic together before I added them to the pot. I also added one fresh sprig of fresh rosemary instead of dried and three Tb of fresh flat leaf parsley.  I added two more cups of water to account for the extra vegetables.  I let the stew sit after the second hour of cooking with the lid on and heat off and it thickened up nicely. Whatever you do, don't add any salt, the bouillon gives it plenty. The family loved it, I will be making this again.  This would be perfect to take to a pot luck.

text:
This is really good! I couldn't get my beef bouillon to crumble as it was hard as a rock, so I just added it to the water and stirred until it dissolved. I seasoned the meat with garlic, onion powder, and black pepper before browning it. I also added a tablespoon each of A-1 sauce and Worcestershire sauce. I thought the stew actually tasted a lot like Sirloin Burger Chunky soup. I do think it would've turned out better if I'd used red wine instead of water, as other reviewers did, and if I'd added some more spices, maybe a little more salt. And I think next time I'll add another cup of water and another bouillon cube - I think I'd like it a little more soupy.

text:
This was excellent and so easy. I made a 5 serving version. I used 2 large red potatoes. I just felt it needed an extra carrot and celery stalk. I also did triple the thickener as someone else suggested. In a bag I put 1/8 cup flour, 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder and 1/4 teaspoon of pepper. Put the stew meat in, and shook it up.   I added a tsp of salt since I used low sodium broth.  Since the serving size was lower I only needed 45 mins on the first simmer and about 40 mins for the vegetables. The meat was very tender.

text:
I am “new” to cooking, so I am not the best, but my fiancé LOVED this beef stew.   It's a super easy recipe to follow (I did not alter) and very tasty.  It was a good feeling to see him help himself to a second bowl.  Some of the other reviews mentioned the bouillon cubes being too salty.  I would agree that you could definitely taste the salt, but I prefer my meals to be seasoned rather than me having to add after the cooking process.  I find the beef stock to be too bland.  It's all about preference.

This recipe was great!!!!  I did use double the water, 4 cups of water didn't seem enough to feed my whole family.  So, I did increase the spices as well.  I followed another reviewers advice, and shook the beef in a bag with flour and spices, before browning. I also used some ketchup and worstershire sacue as well as a can of tomato paste to thicken up to my liking.   Perfect for a cold winter night! Thanks for sharing this recipe with us!

text:
This stew is sooo good!  I used venison stew meat and only made a half batch.  I made it on a snowed in day here in New England so I didn't have any celery or rosemary.  I also used a can of condensed beef broth instead of the bouillon.  It was still amazing.  I followed another review and coated the meat with flour, garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper before browning it.  It was so flavorful!  Pair it with Baking Powder Biscuits and it is the perfect winter meal. This will be my new go-to venison stew recipe!

Display Name:
ReinHart

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good stew, and made it into a crock pot dish.  Ommitted the oil, and used about 1/2 tsp of celery seed since I didn't have any fresh celery.  Also used 2 packets of Washington's Rich Broth in place of the bouillon because its already in a crumbled form. (Will up this the next time, because it wasn't salty enough for my taste)  What I did do though was mix all my spices and some flour in a ziplock bag, then shook the beef cubes a little at a time in the mix, browned them and then put them in the crock pot.  One of the cups of water I put in the pot after I was done browning the beef and got all the trimmings mixed with the water to add to the stew.  Put it on low for 8 hours and it was ready for dinner when the family got home from work.

text:
This was SO good!!  I don't cook very much at all and I managed to impress my husband with this. I made a couple of changes: I coated the beef chunks in a mixture of flour, salt, pepper and garlic seasoning before browning.  Also, I used beef stock instead of bouillon and water.  Because I was short on time I cooked the veggies for about 6 minutes before adding them to the pot and only cooked for 45 minutes instead of an hour.  Last, I used sweet potatoes (it was all I had), and 4 tsp of cornstarch to make it nice and thick!  It was really delicious and hearty.

Very good recipe, but I changed some things.  I used 1lb of meat, which I doused with flour and pepper and browned in the pan.  I substituted 1 can beef broth for the bouillon, plus 1/2 cup water. Only gave four stars as written..however it could be five stars if the following modifications are made...a) use 2 cups water and 2 cups red wine instead of 4 cups water, b) add some garlic powder to the stew meat when browing and c) I ended up using 4-5 TABLEspoons of cornstarch so that I could get a thicker gravy, otherwise its more like soup. All that aside the flavors are wonderful and dont need much modification! Perfect for a cold night with some crusty french bread!

userID:
3247744
Display Name:
Molls
isPro:
False

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/132628.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner tonight.  Very satisfying and delicious.  The rosemary gave this recipe a surprising twist.  Next time I will use only half as much as suggested.  I dredged my beef tips in 1/3 cup flour that was seasoned to taste with onion and garlic powder, garlic pepper, Montreal steak seasoning, and dried parsley. I used 1/2 cup of Merlot wine to deglaze the pot after the meat browned in the oil. I added 6 cups of water that had been mixed with 8 beef bouillon cubes.  It wasn't too much as it cooked off while it simmered for 2hrs.  I only had 1.2lbs of beef stew meat so subbed more veggies but the meat was so tender and delicious that I'll be sure to have more for the next time.  I used half white and half red onion which gave a nice color and flavor.  To thicken I used 2tbs of corn starch with 2 tbs of water...heated the pot to a boil, added the cornstarch mixture and stirred regularly for 2 minutes before returning to a simmer.  It thickened nicely for me.  Made this for my father and boyfriend. My father said it was on his top 5 all time dinners. I'll keep playing with this excellent base until we get it just right.  Thanks for the recipe! Served with crusty french bread that was divine in with the juices!

My husband and daughter both said this was 5 stars (I don't eat meat, so I'll go by their reviews.) The only changes I made were to use about 1/4 cup of sherry to deglaze the pan after browning the flour coated beef cubes, reduced the water to 3 1/2 cups, and added 1 tbsp of cornstarch mixed in 1 tbsp of cold water. The stew still looked pretty runny compared to my usual stew, but nobody seemed to mind. Thanks!

This was so good! I didn't change much.  All I did was season the meat with salt, pepper, garlic, and onion powder. Then I marinated it in vinegar, sealed it and let it sit in the fridge for an hour before cooking. After adding the water and bouillon, I added diced tomatoes,   two tablespoons of worcheshire sauce and a few drops of soy sauce.   After that I followed the recipe step by step. It was a hit! Perfect for a rainy evening. My step mom who is the cook in the house gave it an "A"! Thanks for sharing this recipe!

Probably one of the easiest and tastiest stews around. I floured and seasoned the beef prior to browning and added 1/2 cup of cooking wine to deglaze. During the first simmer process, I added 1 tbsp worchestire and 2 tbsp of ketchup. In addition to the recipe veggies, I also included a can of corn and 2 additional each of celery and carrots. The beef was tender at around 1 hour 45 minutes. The cornstarch was exactly right at the suggested amount in the recipe. Thank you for a great dish!

text:
Made this stew last night and it turned out really well. However, I did make some of the previous suggestions made by previous reviewers. For starters I took a gallon bag and poured flour/salt/pepper into it then tossed in the 2 pounds of stew meat and shook it around until every piece was evenly covered. Next up I added 1 Tablespoon Worcestershire sauce along with 2 bay leaves after adding the water and other seasonings. Lastly I added 3 times the amount of cornstarch to thicken the stew to a consistency that I preferred more. Thats it, otherwise I followed the recipe pretty closely. Made it for my fiance and her family and they all loved it. Going to double up on the amount next time I make as this went FAST!

text:
I gave it five stars. But then I have been making my stew like this for years. Only difference is I use beef broth and not bullion. My husband is allergic to the MSG in bullion. I also use corn instead of onions and celery. My husband is allergic to onions and doesn't like celery. I usually don't use rosemary but since the recipe added it I figured I would try it out. It was good. I crush the rosemary before using it. We like it better that way. I also added more cornstarch as I like a little thicker stew. I would add this to my recipe box but since I already make it like this I don't see a reason to. Thank you

text:
Good recipe but I made some chages.  First, I dredge the beef through a flour/garlic powder mix then sauted in butter (rather then oil).  I then added some worscheshire sauce,2 cups(1 can)of beef broth, 1 cup of beer and 3 cups of water(I needed more water as my stew was super thick and very salty). I used a bag of frozen stew vegetables - which had all the veggies required. I didn't use any cornstarch as mine was thick enough - probably from the flour used to dredge the meat.  Next time will probably use less buillon then called for - Too much salt for me!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this Beef Stew for SOUP DAY @ work,it was a big hit!!I made it for 20 servings.I used a Beef Base(8tsp.)and 1 bouillon cube,instead of all bouillon   cubes,added to 7 1/2 c.of water and 1/2C. Red Cooking Wine,which I boiled first.Added 2Tbl of Tomatoe Paste,2tsp. of Parsley,2tsp. of Rosemary(which I crushed with the bottom of a glass  ),1/4tsp.each; Bl.Pepper,Tyme,Marjoram.
I browned my StewMeat with Flour and 1/4tsp.each Garlic Powder and Bl.Pepper
Added A small can of Corn and Peas.
I also added more Cornstarch and water,along with the left over flour mixture. The juice turned out perfect..not to thin or thick.
Really a GOOD TASTING STEW. This is definetly a KEEPER!!!

Great on a cold day! Added red wine, used 1 1/2 tsp. of arrowroot for thickener instead of cornstarch as it does not make the stew "cloudy".  Mixed it with 1/4 cup of liquid from the stew and added it back in along with frozen peas and cooked for another 5 minutes. Kids and husband loved it!

It was real good and easy to make.  I had to add more cornstarch to get it the consistency I like.  I cooked it for an extra 30 minutes after putting the veggies or they would have been mushy.  I had to add somemore season salt to give it more flavor.  BUT, other than my changes to make it the way I LIKE it, this is an excellent recipe.  Thanks

text:
Just what I was looking for - simply, easy and delicious !
I cooked for a little less time, and only used just under a pound of meat.  I added corn, sweet potatoe and pasta spirals, but didn't add the celery or cornstarch.  Next time I will add rice, or perhaps soaked wild rice instead of the pasta.  Good filler up, and can modify to suit.  Was great even without alot of meat, but good to fill up on vegies if watching your weight.

text:
Excellent and easy to make.  I suggest making sure the meat is in smaller chunks so that it will cook in time.  I had larger cuts and it took 2 hours and 45 minutes to become tender.  Also, I added a sweet potato in place of one of the regular potatoes and it blended into the stew and make it thicker and added a bit of a sweet flavor to it. Yum! This recipe is a keeper!

text:
I followed the recipe almost exactly and it turned out wonderful.  I scaled the recipe down by half and used 1.5 cubes of boullion instead of 2, added an extra cup of water, and added extra veggies.  I found that if you use finely chopped onions, that it helps to thicken the sauce and also adds some flavor.  Like some of the others, however, I did not get the full amount of servings that its supposed to yield.  Instead of 5 servings, I got 3 adult sized servings and one child sized serving.  Overall, I th ink it was a wonderful recipe and am adding it to my favorites!  :)

text:
This was great....I think the rosemary really enhanced the flavor a lot.  Changes I made....I only used 1 TBSP of oil, used 2 tsp of fresh parsley (because I had some I needed to use), added 1 tsp of garlic powder and two bay leaves, and used potato flakes instead of cornstarch to thicken.  It was wonderful.  My husband ate some before I even thickened it.  I have to say just the meat cooking was enough to make your mouth water - it smelled so good.  Thanks for the recipe.
